[[File:Ernst Ludwig Kirchner Bildnis Carl Sternheim 1916.jpg|thumb|[[Ernst Ludwig Kirchner]] portrait of Carl Sternheim 1916]] '''Carl Sternheim''' (born '''William Adolph Carl Francke'''; 1 April 1878 – 3 November 1942) was a [[Germany|German]] [[playwright]] and [[short story]] writer. One of the major exponents of German [[Expressionism]], he especially [[satire|satirized]] the moral sensibilities of the emerging German [[bourgeoisie|middle class]] during the [[William II, German Emperor|Wilhelmine period]].
==Life and career== Sternheim was born in [[Leipzig]], the son of Rosa Marie Flora (née Francke) {1856-1908} and Carl Julius Sternheim {1852-1918}, a banker.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bookrags.com/biography/william-adolf-carl-sternheim-dlb/|title=(William) (Adolf) Carl Sternheim Biography|website=www.bookrags.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OYQYAAAAYAAJ&q=Rosa+Marie+Flora+(Francke&dq=Rosa+Marie+Flora+(Francke&source=bl&ots=JBkP2qUGZK&sig=vk_g5jDk4OCceSbh5BpskQv0WJo&hl=en&redir_esc=y|title=Marbacher magazin|date=9 September 1980|publisher=Deutsche Schillergesellschaft|via=Google Books}}</ref> His parents married two years after he was born.<ref>http://actorstheatre.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/10/UnderpantsStudyGuide.pdf</ref> His father was [[Jew]]ish and his mother was a Lutheran from a working-class family.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sandiego.broadwayworld.com/article/North-Coast-Rep-Presents-San-Diego-Premiere-of-Steve-Martins-Adaptation-of-THE-UNDERPANTS-95-30-20120830|title=North Coast Rep Presents San Diego Premiere of Steve Martin's Adaptation of THE UNDERPANTS, 9/5-10/7|first=BWW News|last=Desk|publisher=}}</ref> Sternheim grew up in [[Hannover]] and [[Berlin]]. Between 1897 and 1902, he studied [[philosophy]], [[psychology]], and [[jurisprudence]] intermittently at the Universities of [[Ludwig Maximilians University of Munich|Munich]], [[Georg-August University of Göttingen|Göttingen]], and [[University of Leipzig|Leipzig]], but never graduated. In 1900, he began working as a [[freelancer|freelance]] writer in [[Weimar]], where he met and married his first wife Eugenie Hauth the same year. Their union ended in 1906 and he married the writer [[Thea Sternheim|Thea Löwenstein]] (née Bauer) in 1907, with whom he had two children. Their daughter Dorothea ("Mopsa") was a resistance fighter during the Second World War and was detained by the Nazi's in [[Ravensbrück concentration camp]].
[[File:Grave Carl Sternheim and Marcel Hastir - Ixelles Bruxelles.jpg|thumb|Grave of Carl Sternheim and [[Marcel Hastir]] in [[Ixelles]]]]The wealth brought by Thea from her rich manufacturing family enabled the couple to build the Schloss Bellemaison in [[Munich]]. Here, Sternheim worked in the company of fellow artists such as [[Mechtilde Lichnowsky]], [[Max Reinhardt (theatre director)|Max Reinhardt]], and [[Frank Wedekind]], and assembled his own art collection. In 1908, he collaborated with [[Franz Blei]] to launch the Expressionist literary journal ''[[Hyperion (journal)|Hyperion]]'', which published the first eight prose works by [[Franz Kafka]]. He also contributed occasionally to the Expressionist journal ''[[Die Aktion]]''. In 1912, he relocated with his family to [[Belgium]] and in 1918, they fled the fighting of [[World War I]] and temporarily moved to [[St. Moritz]] and [[Uttwil]] in [[Switzerland]]. Sternheim and Thea divorced in 1927. His next marriage, to actress and singer [[Pamela Wedekind]], took place in 1930 and lasted until 1934, after which he lived with Henriette Carbonara. Sternheim died in [[Ixelles]] ([[Brussels]])<ref>Archives of the Ixelles Cemetery, Yearbook 1942, last address: Rue Emmanuel Van Driessche 52, Ixelles</ref> during [[World War II]] and was buried in the [[Ixelles Cemetery]]. A friend of his, [[Marcel Hastir]] (1906–2011), was buried in the same tomb.
Sternheim's circle of prominent friends included [[Gottfried Benn]], [[Carl Einstein]], [[Franz Pfemfert]], [[Walther Rathenau]], [[Ernst Stadler]], [[Hugo von Tschudi]], [[Fritz von Unruh]], and [[Otto Vrieslander]]. In 1915, he presented the prize money for the [[Fontane Prize]] to the then largely unknown Kafka. The [[Nazi Germany|Nazi]] authorities banned Sternheim's work not only because of his partial Jewish descent but also because of his savage [[comedy|comedic]] assaults on the perceived moral corruption of the German bourgeoisie.
==Adaptations== Sternheim's works remain popular in [[Germany]], but English language productions of them are rare. This is in part due to the large number of English comedies already in existence, bypassing the need for translations of German comedies. Academics have also argued that Sternheim's works are sometimes hard to sell to the market in foreign languages due to the difficulty in categorising his style as belonging to any one specific movement.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aQqOKWmjdQUC&lpg=PA1280&ots=dzZn_Cw7Gv&dq=%22carl+sternheim%22+fossil&pg=PA1280#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=The Columbia Encyclopedia of Modern Drama|first1=Gabrielle H.|last1=Cody|first2=Evert|last2=Sprinchorn|date=9 September 2018|publisher=Columbia University Press|via=Google Books}}</ref>
As a result, Sternheim's plays have rarely been produced in a major venue. One notable exception occurred when [[Simon Callow]] made his West End debut in a version of ''[[Bürger Schippel]]'' (re-titled as ''The Plumber's Progress'') alongside [[Harry Secombe]] in the 1970s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.whatsonstage.com/interviews/theatre/london/E8821126280713/20+Questions+With%85Simon+Callow.html |title=''20 Questions with Simon Callow|publisher= What's On Stage|date= 12 September 2005 |accessdate=2011-07-15 |df= }}{{dead link|date=January 2017|bot=medic}}</ref> However, in August 2011, both ''[[Bürger Schippel|Paul Schippel Esq.]]'' (an alternative title often given to ''[[Bürger Schippel]]'') and ''[[The Fossil (Play)|The Fossil]]'', another of Sternheim's comedies, were performed as a double-bill at the [[Charing Cross Theatre]], London, with Kieran E. Sims and Alex Corbet Burcher in the respective [[title role]]s.<ref>[http://www.schippelfossil.co.uk ''Latest UK production of Sternheim's "Paul Schippel Esq."]{{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130818034649/http://schippelfossil.co.uk/ |date=2013-08-18 }} </ref>
==Bibliography== *''Aus dem bürgerlichen Heldenleben'' (''From the Heroic Life of the Bourgeois''), [[play cycle]] (1911–22): **''[[The Underpants|Die Hose]]'' (''The Trousers'', also ''The Underpants'')<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.capitalrep.org/pdfs/UnderpantsSG.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-03-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071009113341/http://www.capitalrep.org/pdfs/UnderpantsSG.pdf |archivedate=2007-10-09 |df= }} Steve Martin's ''The Underpants'', production study guide for an adaptation of Sternheim's play at the Capital Repertory Theatre (November 3 – December 2, 2006), "About the Original Playwright", p. 8.</ref> **''Der Snob'' (''The Snob'') **''1913'' **''[[The Fossil (Play)|Das Fossil]]'' (''The Fossil'') **''Die Kassette'' (''The Cartridge'') **''[[Bürger Schippel]]'' (''Citizens Schippel'') *''Schuhlin, Eine Erzahlung'' (''Schuhlin, A Narrative''), (1915) *''Kampf der Metapher'' (''Struggle of Metaphor''), [[essay]] (1917) *''Chronik von des zwanzigsten Jahrhunderts Beginn'' (''Chronicle of the Beginning of the Twentieth Century''), short stories, 1918 *''Die Marquise von Arcis'' (''The Mask of Virtue''), drama (1918) *''Europa'', novel, 2 vol. (1919/1920) *''Manon Lescaut'', drama (1921) *''Oscar Wilde: His Drama'', drama (1925) *''Vorkriegseuropa im Gleichnis meines Lebens'' (''Prewar Europe in the Parable of My Life''), [[memoir]] (1936)
==References== {{Reflist}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20071009113341/http://www.capitalrep.org/pdfs/UnderpantsSG.pdf Steve Martin's ''The Underpants''], production study guide for an adaptation of Sternheim's play at the Capital Repertory Theatre (November 3 – December 2, 2006), "About the Original Playwright", p. 8.
==External links== {{commonscatinline}} *[http://www.carl-sternheim-gesellschaft.de/ Carl Sternheim Society, Frankfurt (in German)] *[http://www.czucka.de/Literaturwissenschaft/Autoren_20_Jhd/Sternheim/CSt_im_Internet/cst_im_internet.html Guide to online resources on Carl Sternheim (in German)] * {{Gutenberg author | id=Sternheim,+Carl | name=Carl Sternheim}} * {{Internet Archive author |sname=Carl Sternheim}}
{{Authority control}}

revision.text:
{{about|[[broadcast automation]]|the cinematic talent agency|Central Casting}} In terrestrial [[radio]] and [[television broadcasting]], '''centralcasting''' refers to the use of systems [[automation]] by which customised signals for broadcast by multiple individual stations may be created at one central facility.
== Definition == Centralcasting is a form of [[broadcast automation]] which operates on the presumption that large quantities of content are similar and are handled in a consistent or repetitive manner across multiple stations in a broadcast station group. While each individual station has its own [[digital on-screen graphic]] logo, [[call sign]] and identity, much of the content on a typical [[affiliate station]] consists of a common [[television network]] or [[syndicated programming]] with a small number of local [[broadcast programming]] time blocks employed for [[television news]] and [[sports television]] coverage, [[public affairs (broadcasting)|public affairs]] programming or local [[television commercials]].
Traditionally, many operations at an individual broadcast station were handled manually by [[broadcast engineering]] technicians at the local station. Network feeds would arrive by [[satellite television|satellite]]; these would contain time cues to indicate when the station could switch to a prerecorded local station break from a [[videotape recorder]], a local station ID from a [[character generator]] or a local program such as a [[newscast]]. Syndicated programming would arrive separately, either recorded in advance from satellite for [[broadcast delay|tape delay]] or transported on prerecorded media. Local [[advertisements]] would be stored on tape cartridges ("carts") which would need to be inserted in the correct timeslots manually. A station could not operate unattended, even if it were merely retransmitting a network [[television program]]me originated elsewhere.
Broadcast automation relies on [[computer]]s to store and retrieve [[video]], largely eliminating the use of individual videotapes and allowing switching and retrieval of stored programming, advertising and titles to take place automatically. The server would operate from stored [[playlist]]s, in which each programme, each commercial advertisement, each live or network feed and each station break had been configured in advance.
=== Central control === In some cases, broadcasters have operated groups of multiple stations at the regional or national level from one central facility, removing many tasks which were formerly done locally. These operations normally take one of two forms:
# A fully centralised operation may have local stations which function as little more than a local news bureau and a [[transmitter]] site. The local station sends its news footage to the central hub, which inserts it (along with local advertising and station identifiers) into a national network or syndicated programming feed. All video is stored in one central location. The resulting broadcast video streams are centrally assembled then sent directly to local station transmitters by the central hub. # A less-centralised approach involves installing servers at local broadcast station sites which may be controlled either locally or remotely. The central hub would be able to send video to the local station, along with playlist information, and local facilities would then be used to store and rebroadcast programming.
=== Non-broadcast operations === Many traffic and operations tasks, such as acquiring programming, selling advertisements, scheduling and keeping records of what was broadcast and billing advertisers take place behind the scenes, yet are also suited to automation and central operation by regional broadcast station groups. If computers handle scheduling of individual broadcasts, advertisements and local identification, a computerised record of what has been broadcast can easily be extracted for use at a central location to bill advertisers for broadcast time. Central operation of non-broadcast business functions removes the need for these tasks to be carried out at each of the multiple local stations.
== Advantages == For some broadcasters, centralisation of broadcasting operations has reduced the number of people required to operate a station, with some saving in cost. This must be carefully balanced, however, against the cost of the extra communications links required from the local station to the hub; these often are [[optical fibre]], [[microwave]] or (occasionally) satellite and can be costly if large amounts of [[digital video]] must be carried great distances.
By shifting many of the control tasks to a central hub, centralcasting may also reduce the investment which must be made in equipment for each individual local station in the group for upgrades such as [[digital television]] broadcasting as less equipment is required at each local station site.<ref>[http://broadcastengineering.com/iptv/ip-based-centralcasting-0601/ IP-based centralcasting, Mark Warner, Broadcast Engineering, Jun 1, 2008] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090130105006/http://broadcastengineering.com/iptv/ip-based-centralcasting-0601/ |date=January 30, 2009 }}</ref>
Centralcasting can also be used as a way to control a station's local operations remotely during off-hours (such as late night, where there may be no one or just a skeleton crew at the local site). This can allow a station to operate on an "auto-pilot" basis during off-hours in which it otherwise may have needed to [[sign-off]].
== Drawbacks == An over-reliance on automation (and a reduction in the number of people at the local station) may leave an individual station less able to respond to local breaking news, such as [[tornado]]es or other [[natural disaster]]s which require local, live and immediate coverage. Individual local stations must also retain enough equipment to handle [[Emergency Alert System]] messages, routing them automatically to any remote locations being used to encode the final broadcast signals.<ref>[http://www.broadcastequipmentguide.com/barix_04_13_07.php Barix IP Audio Devices Gaining Popularity in EAS Applications, Broadcast Equipment Guide, April 13, 2007] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20130119051719/http://www.broadcastequipmentguide.com/barix_04_13_07.php |date=January 19, 2013 }}</ref>
The use of large amounts of centrally assembled programming may also reduce local diversity, turning a station into little more than a [[semi-satellite]] of a main broadcaster in another city. In some cases, individual stations in a group will legally need to maintain nominal main studios in or near their respective [[city of license|communities of license]] but will originate little or nothing from these facilities once most broadcast-related tasks become centralised.<ref>[http://entrepreneur.com/tradejournals/article/75278570_1.html The FCC's main studio rule: achieving little for localism at a great cost to broadcasters, Silverman, David M. - Tobenkin, David N., Federal Communications Law Journal • May 2001] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110813152145/http://entrepreneur.com/tradejournals/article/75278570_1.html |date=August 13, 2011 }}</ref>
Broadcast centralisation can create problems when one station in the group is sold (as the local master control functions which had been centralised must be restored before the local station is a viable stand-alone entity). There also needs to be some means to remain on-air locally if the link to the central hub is lost, lest a [[single point of failure]] take down all stations in the regional group.
== Users == Individual users of centralcasting facilities include: * [[ION Media Networks]] began centralcasting in 2013, and plans to control nearly all owned-and-operated stations from its [[Clearwater, Florida]] broadcast facility. * [[Cox Media Group]] uses centralcasting.<ref>{{cite web|title=Harris Drives Cox Centralcasting|url=http://www.tvtechnology.com/equipment/0082/harris-drives-cox-centralcasting/207575|work=TV Technology|accessdate=19 February 2013|date=29 November 2010}}</ref> * [[Cowles Publishing Company]]'s three Washington stations (which include [[KNDO]] and [[KNDU]] and their [[SWX Right Now]] channels), are operated from a centralcasting facility at flagship station [[KHQ-TV]].<ref name="tvnc-central">{{cite web|title=KHQ Launches Centralcasting With ABS|url=http://www.tvnewscheck.com/article/53645/khq-launches-centralcasting-with-abs?ref=search|publisher=TVNewsCheck|accessdate=18 May 2013}}</ref><ref name="tvnc-khqhd">{{cite web|title=Retrans Deal Drives Cowles Centralcasting|url=http://www.tvnewscheck.com/article/52532/retrans-deal-drives-cowles-centralcasting|publisher=TVNewsCheck|accessdate=18 May 2013}}</ref> * [[Equity Media Holdings]] operated a unique C.A.S.H. (Central Automated Satellite Headend) system which allowed it to programme all of its stations nationwide from one central hub in [[Little Rock, Arkansas]]. Individual station sites in the system were little more than [[satellite television|satellite-fed]] [[broadcast translator]]s.<ref name="EQUITY-MEDIA-HOLDINGS-CORP-Mar-2008-10-K">{{cite web|url=http://pdf.secdatabase.com/944/0001144204-08-019320.pdf |title=EQUITY MEDIA HOLDINGS CORP, Form 10-K, Annual Report, Filing Date Mar 31, 2008 |publisher=secdatabase.com |accessdate =May 15, 2018}}</ref> This system, once one of the largest examples of central [[broadcast automation]], was shut down as a result of Equity's 2009 [[chapter 11]] [[bankruptcy]]. * [[Fisher Communications]] uses centralcasting.<ref>{{cite web|title=Fisher Chooses Omneon For Centralcasting|url=http://www.tvnewscheck.com/article/17231/fisher-chooses-omneon-for-centralcasting|work=TVNewsCheck|accessdate=19 February 2013|date=7 November 2007}}</ref> * [[Fox Television Stations]] centralcasts from [[Las Vegas, Nevada]], a market in which they don't own a station.<ref>{{cite web|title=O'Shea New Fox Stations Master Control|url=http://www.tvnewscheck.com/article/53502/oshea-new-fox-stations-master-control-vp|work=TVNewsCheck|accessdate=26 May 2013|date=25 August 2011}}</ref> * [[TEGNA]] centralcasts its NBC & My Network TV stations from [[Jacksonville, Florida]] and its ABC & CBS Stations from Greensboro, NC<ref name=CPB>{{cite web|last=Behrens|first=Steve|title=CPB to equip 2 pubTV facilities as multistation master controls|url=http://www.current.org/wp-content/themes/current/archive-site/tech/tech1119mastercontrols.html|work=Current.org|accessdate=11 February 2013|date=3 October 2011}}</ref> * [[Hearst Television]] uses centralcasting.<ref>{{cite web|title=Loral Skynet to Provide Hearst-Argyle Television With Customized Satellite Based Solutions.|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Loral+Skynet+to+Provide+Hearst-Argyle+Television+With+Customized...-a084561260|work=The Free Library|accessdate=19 February 2013|date=8 April 2002}}</ref> * [[KQED (TV)|KQED]] originates six [[digital subchannel]]s of programming for sister stations [[KQEH]] [[San Jose, California|San Jose]] and [[KQET]] [[Watsonville, California|Watsonville]]-[[Monterey, California]] in a tapeless/file-based automated operation.<ref>[http://www.tvnewsday.com/articles/2007/07/26/daily.6/ TECH ONE ON ONE WITH NTC'S ETHAN BUSH: IS KQED THE STATION OF THE FUTURE?, TVNEWSDAY, Jul 26 2007]</ref> * [[Meredith Corporation]] controls all of its stations from two hubs. Stations east of the [[Rocky Mountains|Rockies]] are operated from [[WGCL-TV|WGCL]] in [[Atlanta, Georgia]], and all of its stations out West are controlled from [[KPHO-TV|KPHO]] in [[Phoenix, Arizona]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Harris Corporation to Deliver ONE Broadcast Solution to Meredith for New Atlanta Centralcasting Hub|url=http://harrisbroadcast.com/newsandresources/view_pressrelease.asp?act=lookup&pr_id=2803|accessdate=11 February 2013|format=21 September 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130411020459/http://harrisbroadcast.com/newsandresources/view_pressrelease.asp?act=lookup&pr_id=2803|archivedate=11 April 2013|df=}}</ref> * NBC [[Owned-and-operated station|owned and operated stations]] use centralcasting.<ref>{{cite web|title=NBC Selects Marconi For New National Broadband Video Distribution Network|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/nbc-selects-marconi-for-new-national-broadband-video-distribution-network-75771357.html|work=PR Newswire|accessdate=19 February 2013|date=4 February 2002}}</ref> * [[Newport Television]] (now defunct) operated [[New York State|New York]] Digital CentralCasting facilities at [[WSYR-TV]] [[Syracuse, New York|Syracuse]] to serve former Ackerley stations<ref>[http://www.digitalbroadcasting.com/article.mvc/Ackerley-links-member-stations-via-centralcas-0001 Ackerley links member stations via centralcasting; DigitalBroadcasting.com; May 17, 2001] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110710124737/http://www.digitalbroadcasting.com/article.mvc/Ackerley-links-member-stations-via-centralcas-0001 |date=July 10, 2011 }}</ref> in [[Binghamton, New York|Binghamton]], [[Elmira, New York|Elmira]], [[Rochester, New York|Rochester]] and [[Watertown, New York|Watertown]] with additional regional hubs serving [[Oregon]] and [[California]] stations. * [[Nexstar Media Group]] uses centralcasting. * [[Post-Newsweek Stations]] centralcasts from Jacksonville, Florida.<ref name=CPB /> * Some [[Public Broadcasting Service|PBS]] member stations are using centralcasting facilities on a limited scale as a means to deploy additional [[digital subchannel]]s and remotely monitor unattended overnight broadcast operations.<ref>[http://www.current.org/tech/tech0322eiop.shtml PBS offer: automated control room in a box, Steve Behrens, Current, Dec. 1, 2003] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090101024544/http://www.current.org/tech/tech0322eiop.shtml |date=January 1, 2009 }}</ref> * PBS SoCal is locating its technical facilities at the Centralcast location in the Los Angeles Sawtelle district * [[Radio-Canada]] generates individualised [[French language]] television feeds for each of multiple [[Canadians|Canadian]] [[time zone]]s from one facility in [[Montreal]]<ref>[http://broadcastengineering.com/infrastructure/broadcasting_cbcradiocanadas_move_centralcasting CBC/Radio-Canada's move to centralcasting, Sep 1, 2005, Broadcast Engineering, CBC/RADIO-CANADA BROADCAST ENGINEERING GROUP] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090130001448/http://broadcastengineering.com/infrastructure/broadcasting_cbcradiocanadas_move_centralcasting |date=January 30, 2009 }}</ref> * [[Raycom Media]] uses centralcaasting.<ref>{{cite web|last=Barthold|first=Jim|title=Outsourcing Master Control Gains Traction|url=http://www.tvnewscheck.com/article/33551/outsourcing-master-control-gains-traction|work=TVNewsCheck|accessdate=19 February 2013|date=2 July 2009}}</ref> * [[Sinclair Broadcast Group]] uses centralcasting.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sinclair Speeds Centralcasting|url=http://www.broadcastingcable.com/article/147538-Sinclair_Speeds_Centralcasting.php|work=Broadcasting & Cable|accessdate=11 February 2013|date=5 January 2003}}</ref> * [[Time Warner Cable]] operates four [[24-hour news cycle|24-hour]] [[cable news]] channels ([[YNN Central New York]], [[YNN Rochester]], [[YNN Buffalo]], and [[YNN Capital Region]]) from two hubs, one (for news anchoring) in Albany and the other (for all weather operations) in Syracuse. While the news channels mostly use different anchors for each station, all four stations get their weather forecasts from the same team of meteorologists.<ref name=TWC>{{cite web|last=Kerschbaumer|first=Ken|title=Straight Out of Centralcasting|url=http://www.broadcastingcable.com/article/96104-Straight_Out_of_Centralcasting.php|accessdate=11 February 2013|date=5 October 2005}}</ref> * [[Tribune Broadcasting]] centralcasts its stations.<ref name=TWC /> * [[WCNY-TV]], the PBS station based in Central New York State, hosts Centralcast LLC, which broadcast PBS content to over 20 stations in over 9 states. This represents 40% of PBS content in the USA.<ref>http://centralcast.org/</ref><ref>http://www.tvtechnology.com/news/0086/ny-pubcasters-centralize-master-control/215517</ref> * The majority of [[Wisconsin Public Television]]'s operations for its six full-power and translator television stations originate from the public broadcaster's [[Madison, Wisconsin]] facility, with the other stations in the network mainly maintaining only basic engineering and studio operations in their [[city of license]]. This arrangement is common for statewide [[Public Broadcasting System|PBS]] and [[National Public Radio|NPR]] networks such as Kentucky's [[KET]], Nebraska's [[Nebraska Educational Telecommunications|NET]], [[Georgia Public Broadcasting]] in the state of Georgia, and [[Oklahoma Educational Television Authority|OETA]] serving the state of Oklahoma. America's First was [[Alabama Public Television]] in 1955.
== Controversy == Some groups, such as [[Sinclair Broadcast Group]], have attempted to centralise not only routine operational tasks but also the production of [[local news]].<ref>Managing Television News: A Handbook for Ethical and Effective Producing; page 227; B. William Silcock, Don Heider, Mary T. Rogus; Routledge, 2007; {{ISBN|978-0-8058-5373-5}}</ref> The [[News Central]] format, which Sinclair abandoned in 2006,<ref>[https://ls2.cmich.edu/cgi-bin/wa?A2=ind0611&L=AEJMC&P=60 A Centralcasting Postmortem and a News-Share Projection: Using Market Theory to Assess Alternative Local Television News Strategies; AEJMC Annual Convention - Radio-Television Journalism Division, August 2–6, 2006]</ref> involved inserting small blocks of local content into an otherwise-national newscast,<ref>[https://www.pbs.org/newshour/bb/media/july-dec03/newscentral_12-11.html Online Focus: CENTRAL CASTING, PBS NewsHour, December 11, 2003]</ref> which would then be presented to local viewers as having been generated at the local station.<ref>[http://www.newslab.org/articles/centralcasting.htm LOCAL NEWS, FROM FAR AWAY: "Centralcasting" saves money but could impair coverage, Deborah Potter, American Journalism Review, April 2003]</ref>
The resulting product contains largely the same content (and potentially the same [[journalistic bias]]es) in each market in which it appears,<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2003/06/02/business/tv-news-that-looks-local-even-if-it-s-not.html TV News That Looks Local, Even if It's Not, JIM RUTENBERG / MICHELINE MAYNARD, New York Times, June 2, 2003]</ref> raising objections from proponents of localism and opponents of [[concentration of media ownership]].
The reduction in local broadcast-related jobs as tasks are moved to central locations has also drawn objections from [[trade union]]s.<ref>[https://www.friends.ca/news-item/2052 Union appeals CRTC ruling to Federal Court of Appeal, April 2008, Canada NewsWire]</ref>
== See also == * [[Automatic transmission system]] * [[Broadcast automation]] * [[Station identification]] and [[local insertion]] * [[Video server]] and [[playout]]
== References == {{reflist}}
