[[File:Guardians of the Galaxy-Logo.png|thumb|Guardians of the Galaxy logo]] The '''Guardians of the Galaxy''' is a fictional [[superhero team]] appearing in [[American comic book]]s published by [[Marvel Comics]]. Specifically it may refer to:
==Comic book teams== * [[Guardians of the Galaxy (1969 team)]], the original 31st-century team from an alternate timeline * [[Guardians of the Galaxy (2008 team)]], the modern version of the team formed in the aftermath of ''Annihilation: Conquest'' *[[Guardians of the Galaxy (2008 team)|Guardians of the Galaxy (New Guard)]], consisting of [[Kitty Pryde]], [[Thing (comics)|Thing]], [[Drax the Destroyer|Drax]], [[Venom (Marvel Comics character)|Venom]], [[Rocket Raccoon]], [[Groot]], and later [[Star-Lord]] and [[Gamora]]
==Media== * [[Guardians of the Galaxy (film)|''Guardians of the Galaxy'' (film)]], the 2014 film based on the 2008 comic book version ** [[Guardians of the Galaxy (soundtrack)|''Guardians of the Galaxy'' (soundtrack)]], the soundtrack for the film ** [[Guardians of the Galaxy (TV series)|''Guardians of the Galaxy'' (TV series)]], an animated series inspired by the film ** [[Guardians of the Galaxy: The Telltale Series|''Guardians of the Galaxy'' (video game)]], an episodic [[video game]] series, developed by [[Telltale Games]], inspired by the film * ''[[Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2]]'', the 2017 sequel to the 2014 film * ''[[Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2#Sequel|Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3]]'', the upcoming sequel to the 2017 film
==Other uses== * ''[[Guardians of the Galaxy – Mission: Breakout!]]'', a theme park ride at [[Disney California Adventure]] *[[Guardians of the Galaxy (roller coaster)|''Guardians of the Galaxy'' (roller coaster)]], under construction at [[Epcot]]
==See also== *[[List of Guardians of the Galaxy members]] *[[Guardians of the Universe]], an unrelated race from DC Comics
{{Guardians of the Galaxy}}
{{Set index article|comics}}
[[Category:Guardians of the Galaxy]]

{{Infobox comedian | image = Igor Ilyinsky - Three Millions Trial 2.jpg | imagesize = 210px | caption= Igor Ilyinsky as Tapioka in the film ''[[The Three Million Trial]]''. [[1926 in film|1926]]. | name = Igor Ilyinsky |honorific suffix=[[Hero of Socialist Labour|HSL]] [[People's Artist of the USSR|PAU]]| birth_name = Igor Vladimirovich Ilyinsky | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1901|7|24}} | birth_place = [[Moscow]], [[Russian Empire]] (present-day [[Moscow, Russia]]) | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|1987|1|13|1901|7|24}} | death_place = [[Moscow]], [[Soviet Union]] (present-day [[Moscow, Russia]]) |resting_place = [[Novodevichy Cemetery]], [[Moscow]] | genre = Slapstick, mime, comedy | spouse = Tatiana Ilyinskaya (c. 1920-1945; her death)
Tatyana Yeremeeva (1951-1987; his death)}} '''Igor Vladimirovich Ilyinsky''' ({{lang-ru|И́горь Влади́мирович Ильи́нский}}; 24 July 1901 – 13 January 1987) was a famous [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] and [[Russians|Russian]] film and stage actor, director and comedian. [[Hero of Socialist Labour]] (1974) and [[People's Artist of the USSR]] (1949). ==Early years== Igor Ilyinsky was born on 24 July 1901 in Moscow. At age 16 he entered the Theatre Studio of [[Theodore Komisarjevsky]] and in half a year already debuted on the professional stage in [[Komissarjevsky Theatre]]. His first theatre role was that of the "Old Man" in [[Aristophanes]]' play ''[[Lysistrata]]''. In 1920, he joined the [[Vsevolod Meyerhold]] Theatre. The young actor's style was in correspondence with the principles of Meyerhold, and so Ilyinsky soon became the central actor of that theatre. ==Career in silent cinema== In the mid-1920s Ilyinsky started to appear in movies, where he also played vivid comic characters. In 1924, [[Yakov Protazanov]] featured him in his famous futuristic film ''[[Aelita]]'', which was followed by his role in Protazanov's comedy ''[[The Tailor from Torzhok]]'' (1925). In 1926, he appeared in three films.
“I can act on the roof of a train carriage, on the radiator of a moving car, on back of a galloping horse, or while swimming in the sea”.
==1930s-1950s== In 1938 he joined the [[Maly Theatre (Moscow)|Maly Theatre]] that had been his favourite one since school years. Afterwards Ilyinsky stayed in the Maly Theatre for almost fifty years and even staged several plays there himself. Ilyinsky would later write that it was [[Russian literature|Russian classic literature]] that had helped him overcome the crisis and feeling that he had been unable to create new characters, different from the previous ones. An outstandingly prolific period in the actor’s life was related to his work with the famous film director [[Grigori Aleksandrov]]. In 1938 Ilyinsky splendidly acted as Byvalov in the comedy [[Volga-Volga]] (for this role, he was awarded [[Stalin Prize]] in 1941). He deliberately avoided any comic traits in his character to create a common image of a red-tapist. The starting point for him was the gracious and stirring character of [[Lyubov Orlova]]. He decided to create a totally contrasting character, which he succeeded in. That role brought Ilyinsky the State Prize. [[Joseph Stalin|Stalin]] reportedly watched the film sixteen times. At Molotov's birthday party Stalin flung Ilyinsky a remark: “Ah, Byvalov! You are a bureaucrat and I am a bureaucrat. We shall understand each other”. The success of that movie determined the development of Soviet film comedy for the next several decades. However, after the film Ilyinsky almost stopped his film acting. In the mid-1950s Ilyinsky finally got a chance to act in a movie. It was a light comedy, ''[[A Crazy Day]]''. The character created by Ilyinsky was a repetition of what he had done 20 years earlier. He managed to play a truly starry film role only 18 years after Volga-Volga. It was the role of the bureaucrat Ogurtsov in the smash-hit comedy ''[[The Carnival Night]]'', directed by [[Eldar Ryazanov]].
''“I was not going to feature the great Igor Ilyinsky in The Carnival Night - I felt timid, and understood that being a coryphaeus he would suppress me. When Pyriev offered him for the role of Ogurtsov, I just panicked: he was my idol from childhood, the famous actor of the Meyerhold Theatre! And me, directing my first film, on the other scale!”'' (Eldar Ryazanov)
==Later years== In Maly Theatre at the same time Ilyinsky shifted to portrayals of deeply tragic characters, in particular, from [[Fyodor Dostoyevsky]] and [[Leo Tolstoy]]. In the late 1960s Ilyinsky went into stage directing. His first stage production was the stage version of [[Gustave Flaubert]]'s popular novel ''[[Madame Bovary]]''. The last period of Ilyinsky’s career was marked by his portrayal of [[Leo Tolstoy]] in the play ''Turning Full Circle and of Firs'', and his performance in ''[[The Cherry Orchard]]'' by [[Anton Chekhov]]. As a very old person Igor Ilyinsky acted a lot on the radio – almost blind, he was accompanied to the studio. ==Death== Igor Ilyinsky died on 13 January 1987, aged 85. His widow, actress [[Tatyana Yeremeyeva]], died on 29 November 2012, aged 99.[http://kommersant.ru/doc/2078633 Notice of death of Tatyana Yeremeyeva] ==Legacy== * A [[minor planet]] [[3622 Ilinsky]], discovered by [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] astronomer [[Lyudmila Zhuravlyova]] in 1981 is named after Igor Ilyinsky.{{cite book|last=Schmadel|first=Lutz D.|title=Dictionary of Minor Planet Names|edition=5th|year=2003|publisher=Springer Verlag|location=New York|url=https://books.google.com/books?q=3622+Ilinsky+1981|isbn=3-540-00238-3|page=305}} ==Filmography== [[File:Волга-Волга-кадр-2.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Igor Ilyinsky as Byvalov in the film ''[[Volga-Volga]]''. [[1938 in film|1938]].]] *1976: "[[This Is the House That Jack Built]]" (short) as Narrator (voice) *1974: ''[[Yunga severnogo flota]]'' *1973: ''[[Eti raznye, raznye litsa]]'' *1969: ''[[Staryy znakomyy]]'' *1962: [[Dinner Time (1962 film)|''Dinner Time'']] *1962: ''[[Hussar Ballad]]'' as [[Mikhail Kutuzov]] *1956: ''[[Crazy Day (film)|Crazy Day]]'' (Безумный день) as Zajtsev *1956: ''[[The Carnival Night]]'' as Serafim Ivanovich Ogurtsov *1953: "[[Zvanyy uzhin]]" (short) *1952: ''[[Woe from Wit]]'' as Anton Antonovich Zagoretski *1952: ''[[Na vsyakogo mudretsa dovolno prostoty]]'' as Krutitsky *1952: ''[[Wolves and Sheep (film)|Wolves and Sheep]]'' as Appolon Murzavetsky *1938: ''[[Volga-Volga]]'' as Byvalov *1936: ''[[Odnazhdy letom]]'' as Teleskop/professor Sen-Verbuda *1931: ''[[Shakhta 12-28]]'' as The Angel *1930: ''[[St. Jorgen's Day]]'' as Franz Schulz *1928: ''[[Kukla s millionami]]'' as Pierre Cuisinai *1927: ''[[A Kiss From Mary Pickford]]'' as Goga *1926: ''[[Miss Mend]]'' as Tom Hopkins, clerk *1926: ''[[The Three Million Trial]]'' as Tapioka *1925: ''[[The Tailor from Torzhok]]'' as Petya Petelkin *1924: ''[[Papirosnitsa ot Mosselproma]]'' as Nikodim Mityushin, bookkeeper *1924: ''[[Aelita]]'' as Kravtsov, amateur sleuth ==Honours and awards== [[File:Igor Ilyinsky Postal card Russia 2001.jpg|thumb|right|280x200px|Igor Ilyinsky as the Governor in ''[[The Government Inspector ]]'' ([[Maly Theatre (Moscow)|Maly Theatre]], 1952). The [[postal card]] issued to commemorate the birth centenary of the actor. [[Russian Post]], 2001.]] * [[Hero of Socialist Labour]] (1974) * Three [[Orders of Lenin]] (1967, 1971, 1974) * [[Order of the October Revolution]] (1986) * [[Order of the Red Banner of Labour]], three times (1939, 1949 and 1961) * [[Order of Friendship of Peoples]] (1981) * [[People's Artist of the USSR]] (1949) * [[Lenin Prize]] (1980) * [[Stalin Prize]], 1st class, three times ** for his role as Byvalov in the 1938 film "Volga-Volga" (1941) ** for his role of garlic in the play "In the steppes of Ukraine" AE Korneichuk (1942) ** for his role in the play "Unforgettable 1919" by V. Vishnevskyand (1951) ==See also== *[[Vsevolod Meyerhold]] *[[Yakov Protazanov]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Commonscat|Igor Ilyinsky|Igor Ilyinsky}} *{{IMDb name|0407970}} *[http://www.teatral-online.ru/news/1633/ "A modest life of jolly comedian" (in Russian)] *[http://www.infornews.ru/cinema/7302.html Fragments from autobiography (in Russian)]{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ilyinsky, Igor}} [[Category:1901 births]] [[Category:1987 deaths]] [[Category:Male actors from Moscow]] [[Category:Silent film comedians]] [[Category:Russian male stage actors]] [[Category:Russian male silent film actors]] [[Category:Russian male film actors]] [[Category:Soviet male stage actors]] [[Category:Soviet male film actors]] [[Category:People's Artists of the USSR]] [[Category:Heroes of Socialist Labour]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of Lenin]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of Friendship of Peoples]] [[Category:Lenin Prize winners]] [[Category:Stalin Prize winners]] [[Category:Modernist theatre]]

revision.text:
{{one source|date=August 2017}} The '''King Rising levitation''' is a [[Levitation (illusion)|levitation illusion]] developed by and named after Corey King. Some consider it to be a variation of the [[Balducci levitation]].
==Effect== The performer is viewed from the side. The performer's legs may be covered (commonly with a jacket) at the beginning of the effect. At this point the performer may patter, saying something like, “You may have seen other magicians levitate behind a jacket...". This is a reference to the [[Superman]] levitation. The obstruction (jacket, etc.) would then be removed. The performer's whole body is clearly visible. The performer suddenly appears to levitate a few inches above the ground. Both feet are clearly seen to be in the air. The levitation usually lasts just a few seconds. When both feet return to the ground, the performer's legs may again be momentarily obscured. The performer may again make a comparative reference to the Superman levitation. Immediately afterwards the effect is complete, and the performer (particularly the performer's clothing) and the area around the performer can be thoroughly examined.
[[Image:Kingrisinglevitation2.nwr.jpg|thumb|right|The King Rising levitation being performed]]
The biggest advantage of this levitation effect is that it is (like the [[Balducci levitation]]) impromptu. It can be performed anytime, anywhere, as long as the performer is wearing pants and shoes. It is more believable than the Balducci levitation because both feet are clearly seen in the air. However, it does require a small set-up that must be done under some kind of cover (an obstruction or [[misdirection (magic)|misdirection]]). It is also considerably more difficult to perform than the Balducci levitation.
==Method==
The performer stands so as to be viewed from the side. Under cover, the performer removes his or her foot from the far shoe and positions it at a right angle to that shoe, with the heel of the foot placed against the side of the shoe. After the obstruction is removed, the front of the performer's body can be seen. From the spectator's perspective it is impossible to tell that the performer's foot is out, because it is hidden by the leg closest to the viewers. The performer's weight is shifted to the leg, and the empty shoe is pinched between the angled foot and the shoe closest to the audience. The performer stands on the tip of the foot. Again, the foot remains hidden behind the shoes, which are both physically in the air, creating the genuine levitation. To end the effect the process is simply reversed.
The key to this illusion is that the spectators assume that there is a foot inside of the shoe, which is only natural. When both shoes are seen above the ground, it is then assumed that both feet are above the ground, and the performer is levitating.
Note that an obstruction is generally used to hide the performer's action of removing, and replacing the foot in its shoe. It is possible however to perform the effect without ever covering the legs, by using misdirection.<ref>{{cite video |people= |date= |title=King Rising Levitation - How To Levitate or Float |url=http://www.ellusionist.com/king-rising-levitation.html |format=DVD |medium= |publisher=Ellusionist |location= |accessdate= |time= |quote= }}</ref>
==See also== * [[Magic (illusion)]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:King Levitation}} [[Category:Magic tricks]]
[[pl:Lewitacja King Rising]]

{{About|the superhero film|the video game|Megamind (video game)|the short film|Megamind: The Button of Doom|}} {{Use mdy dates|date=January 2012}} {{Infobox film | name = Megamind | image = Megamind2010Poster.jpg | alt = Poster showing primary characters; from left to right: Metro Man, Minion, Megamind, Roxanne and Tighten. | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Tom McGrath (animator)|Tom McGrath]] | producer = {{plainlist| * [[Lara Breay]] * Denise Nolan Cascino }} | writer = {{plainlist| * Alan J. Schoolcraft * Brent Simons *Katherine Spafford }} | starring = {{plainlist| * [[Will Ferrell]] * [[Tina Fey]] * [[Jonah Hill]] * [[David Cross]] * [[Brad Pitt]] }} | music = {{plainlist| * [[Hans Zimmer]] * [[Lorne Balfe]] }} | editing = Michael Andrews | studio = {{plainlist| * [[DreamWorks Animation]] * [[Pacific Data Images]] }} | distributor = [[Paramount Pictures]]<ref name=afi>{{cite web|url=http://www.afi.com/members//catalog/DetailView.aspx?s=&Movie=66547|title=Megamind|work=[[American Film Institute]]|accessdate=2016-10-26}}</ref> | released = {{Film date|2010|10|28|Russia|2010|11|5|United States}} | runtime = 96 minutes<ref>{{cite web|title=Megamind (2D)|url=http://www.bbfc.co.uk/releases/megamind-2010-0|publisher=British Board of Film Classification|accessdate=December 11, 2013}}</ref> | country = United States | language = English | budget = $130 million<ref name="Box Office">{{cite web|title=Megamind|url= http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=mastermind.htm|work= [[Box Office Mojo]] |accessdate=October 13, 2012}}</ref> | gross = $321.9 million<ref name="Box Office" /> }} '''''Megamind''''' is a 2010 American [[3D Film|3D]] [[Computer-animated film|computer-animated]] [[Superhero film|superhero]] [[comedy film]] directed by [[Tom McGrath (animator)|Tom McGrath]], produced by [[DreamWorks Animation]] and distributed by [[Paramount Pictures]]. The film premiered on October 28, 2010, in [[Russia]], while it was released in the United States in [[Digital 3D]], [[IMAX 3D]] and 2D on November 5, 2010. It features the voices of [[Will Ferrell]], [[Tina Fey]], [[Jonah Hill]], [[David Cross]], and [[Brad Pitt]].<ref name="superherohype">{{cite web | author=SuperHeroHype | url=http://www.superherohype.com/news/articles/99311-ferrell-pitt-and-hill-to-voice-oobermind | title=Ferrell, Pitt and Hill to voice Oobermind | publisher=[[Superhero Hype!]] | date=August 16, 2009 | accessdate=August 18, 2009}}</ref>
The film tells the story of a super-intelligent alien supervillain, Megamind, who after a long-lasting battle one day actually destroys his foe, the much-loved superhero Metro Man. Having Metro City for himself, Megamind finds out that his villainy has no purpose and thus creates a new superhero to serve as his nemesis. His plan backfires, as he ends up creating instead a new super-villain. With Metro City spiraling out of control, Megamind attempts to set things right and discovers his newfound purpose—as a superhero.
''Megamind'' received generally positive reviews from critics, praising its strong visuals and the cast's performances, but criticizing its unoriginality.<ref name="rt"/> With a budget of $130 million, the film grossed over $321 million worldwide,<ref name="Box Office" /> becoming one of DreamWorks Animation's lowest-grossing CG animated films of the 2000s.<ref>{{cite news|last=Fritz|first=Ben|title='Megamind' less than a mega-success overseas|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2011/jan/03/entertainment/la-et-box-office-sidebar-20110103|accessdate=September 3, 2012|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=January 3, 2011}}</ref>
A short film, titled ''[[Megamind: The Button of Doom]]'', was released on February 25, 2011, on the ''Megamind'' DVD and Blu-ray.
==Plot== Ever since they arrived on Earth as infants, supervillain Megamind has fought superhero Metro Man for dominance of Metro City. In his latest plan, Megamind and his sidekick Minion kidnap reporter Roxanne Ritchi and hold her hostage in a copper-lined observatory. When Metro Man arrives to save her, he reveals he is weakened by copper, and Megamind obliterates him with a death ray. Megamind finally takes control of the city, but his celebration is short-lived as without Metro Man to challenge him, he finds his life has no meaning.
While wandering the recently-opened Metro Man Museum, Megamind sees Roxanne nearby, and uses his holographic disguise watch to take the form of Bernard, the museum's curator, whom he had "dehydrated" into a small cube. He talks to Roxanne and becomes attracted to her, and is inspired by one of her statements to create a new superhero for him to fight. Megamind returns to his lair and creates a serum containing Metro Man's DNA which he plans to inject into a proper candidate with his Defuser Gun. However, Roxanne's arrival at his lair with her dimwitted cameraman Hal Stewart causes Megamind to inadvertently inject Hal with the serum. Megamind disguises himself as Hal's "Space Dad" and convinces him to become the superhero "Titan". Titan spends several days training with his Space Dad before issuing a challenge to fight Megamind.
On the day before the fight, Megamind gets into an argument with Minion about giving up villainy for Roxanne, while Titan tries and fails to woo her. Megamind, disguised as Bernard, takes Roxanne on a dinner date. Titan sees them, and as he had been infatuated with Roxanne, becomes upset and leaves. Shortly thereafter, Megamind's disguise fails, revealing his identity to Roxanne, who also storms off. The situation leaves him unable to find his invisible car, which is where he left the Defuser Gun he used to inject the serum into Hal.
Titan does not arrive at the scheduled fight, and Megamind finds that he has used his abilities for criminal purposes. As "Space Dad" and "Bernard" Megamind successfully convinces Titan to fight him as Titan realizes Megamind has used him and "taken" Roxanne from him. Titan engages in a super-powered fight with Megamind and his mechs hit. However, when Titan wants to ''kill'' him instead of arrest him, Megamind lures Titan into a copper-lined trap, but he is unaffected and continues to fight. Megamind escapes from the battle and seeks out Roxanne, hoping she can help. She offers to take him to Metro Man's secret headquarters, where they are both surprised to find Metro Man alive. Metro Man faked his death and weakness to copper, as he had become tired of being a superhero and wanted to retire to become a music star. He declines to help, but offers Megamind the advice that a hero will always rise up to challenge evil.
Returning to the city, Megamind does not believe he can become the hero the city needs, and allows himself to be locked up in prison. Titan kidnaps Roxanne and demands Megamind show himself or else. Megamind has a change of heart and pleads with the prison warden, apologizing for his past actions. The warden reveals himself to be Minion in disguise, accepting Megamind's apology, and frees him so they can fight Hal.
As Hal is about to kill Roxanne, Megamind appears and frees her. The two escape, but Hal traps Megamind under rubble when Metro Man suddenly arrives, and Hal flees. Roxanne discovers that "Megamind" is really an injured Minion in disguise, while "Metro Man" is Megamind. Hal, in his flight, recognizes Megamind's distinctive mispronunciations, and realizes he was duped. Hal flies back and fights Megamind, during which Megamind finds his invisible car. He grabs the Defuser Gun and is able to extract the Metro Man serum from Titan, restoring him to normal. Hal is arrested for his crimes. Now hailed as heroes, Megamind and Minion appear at the reopening of Metro Man's museum, now dedicated to Megamind instead, while Metro Man, in disguise within the crowd, silently congratulates his former rival.
In a [[mid-credits scene]] Minion is doing the laundry when a re-hydrated Bernard pops out of the washing machine.
==Voice cast== {{multiple image |direction=vertical |total_width = 150 |image1=Will Ferrell as MegaMind by Gage Skidmore.jpg |image2=Tina Fey by Gage Skidmore.jpg |image3=Jonah Hill by Gage Skidmore.jpg |footer=Will Ferrell, Tina Fey and Jonah Hill at the 2010 [[San Diego Comic-Con International]] |footer_align=center }} * [[Will Ferrell]] as Megamind, an extraterrestrial mastermind who turns from [[supervillain]] to [[superhero]]. He is a spoof of [[Lex Luthor]] and [[Brainiac (character)|Brainiac]],<ref>{{cite web|last=Greydanus|first=Steven D.|title='Megamind' a Clever Spoof|url=http://www.ncregister.com/site/article/megamind-a-clever-spoof/|work=National Catholic Register|date=November 11, 2010|accessdate=August 29, 2011}}</ref> while his "Space Dad" persona is a parody of both [[Jor-El]] as played by [[Marlon Brando]] in the 1978 film ''[[Superman (1978 film)|Superman]]'' and Brando's performance as [[Vito Corleone]] in ''[[The Godfather]]''.<ref name="LATFerrelChannelsBrando">{{cite news|last1=Boucher|first1=Geoff|title=Will Ferrell channels Brando in ‘Megamind’? ‘Yes, I do, isn’t that weird?’|url=http://herocomplex.latimes.com/movies/will-ferrell-channels-brando-in-megamind-yes-i-do-isnt-that-weird/|accessdate=April 23, 2017|work=Los Angeles Times|date=November 7, 2010}}</ref> The DVD commentary notes that his costume and showmanship are purposely evocative of [[Alice Cooper]]. * [[Tina Fey]] as Roxanne "Roxie" Ritchi, a TV news reporter who becomes Megamind's love interest. She is a spoof of [[Lois Lane]].<ref name=io9>{{cite news|last=Wilkins|first=Alasdair|title=Megamind asks the great superhero question: what if Lex Luthor killed Superman?|url=http://io9.com/5594075/megamind-asks-the-ultimate-superhero-question-what-if-lex-luthor-killed-superman-once-and-for-all|accessdate=August 29, 2011|newspaper=io9|date=July 22, 2010}}</ref> * [[Jonah Hill]] as Hal Stewart/Titan,<ref>{{cite web|title="Megamind" screenplay|url=http://screenplayexplorer.com/?tag=megamind-script|publisher=Screenplay Explorer|accessdate=December 29, 2011|date=December 3, 2010}}</ref> Roxanne Ritchi's hapless, dimwitted but nerdy cameraman who has unrequited feelings for her. His motivation throughout the film is to get her back to his apartment with him. He later becomes a villain named Titan (he misspells "Tighten"). The name ''Hal Stewart'' refers to [[Hal Jordan]] and [[John Stewart (comics)|John Stewart]] of the [[Green Lantern Corps]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Knolle|first=Sharon|title=A Moviefone Salute to Guys Named Hal|url=http://blog.moviefone.com/2011/06/17/movie-characters-named-hal/|work=Moviefone|date=June 17, 2011|accessdate=August 29, 2011}}</ref> * [[David Cross]] as Minion, a [[Wisdom#Sapience|sapient]] talking fish who has been Megamind's sidekick and best friend since childhood. His costume is evocative of Ro-Man from [[Robot Monster]]. * [[Brad Pitt]] as Metro Man, Megamind's former nemesis. He is a spoof of [[Superman]].<ref name=io9 /> The DVD commentary notes that his costume and showmanship are purposely evocative of the late [[Elvis Presley]]. * [[J. K. Simmons]] as the Warden, the no-nonsense head of Metro City Prison. * [[Ben Stiller]] as Bernard, a museum curator whom Megamind impersonates to win Roxanne's affections. * [[Christopher Knights]] as a prison guard. * [[Tom McGrath (animator)|Tom McGrath]] as Lord Scott and a prison guard. * [[Jack Blessing]] as Newscaster. * [[Justin Theroux]] as Megamind's father. * Jessica Schulte as Megamind's mother.
==Production== [[File:Tom McGrath (4840304838).jpg|thumb|Director Tom McGrath promoting the film at the 2010 San Diego Comic-Con International]] The film was written by Alan J. Schoolcraft and Brent Simons.<ref name="onehugeeye">{{cite web|url=http://www.onehugeeye.com/dreamworks-reveals-voice-cast-for-oobermind.html|title=DreamWorks reveals voice-cast for Oobermind|publisher=One Huge Eye|date=August 17, 2009|author=Alex Amelines|accessdate=August 18, 2009}}</ref> It was first titled ''Master Mind'', and then ''Oobermind''.<ref name="bamkapow">{{cite web|url=http://www.bamkapow.com/post.phtml?pk=3294|title=Master Mind" becomes "Oobermind|publisher=Bam! Kapow!|author=Skott Stotland|date=May 28, 2009|accessdate=August 18, 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707210122/http://www.bamkapow.com/post.phtml?pk=3294|archivedate=2011-07-07}}</ref> It was suggested that Ben Stiller would be cast as Megamind,<ref name="Master">{{cite web|url=http://blog.moviefone.com/2007/04/03/ben-stiller-is-a-master-mind/|title=Ben Stiller is a Master Mind|publisher=MovieFone|author=Christopher Campbell|date=April 3, 2007|accessdate=May 3, 2013}}</ref> and later [[Robert Downey, Jr.]]<ref name=VarietyOutput>{{cite news|last=Debruge|first=Peter|title=DreamWorks animates its output|url=https://variety.com/2009/film/news/dreamworks-animates-its-output-1118004228/|accessdate=May 21, 2014|newspaper=Variety|date=May 27, 2009}}</ref> but [[Will Ferrell]] was ultimately given the role, due to "scheduling conflicts" for Downey.<ref name="superherohype"/><ref>[http://collider.com/will-ferrell-replaces-robert-downey-jr-in-dreamworks-animations-oobermind/ Will Ferrell Replaces Robert Downey Jr. in DreamWorks Animation’s OOBERMIND] Retrieved May 3, 2013</ref> [[Lara Breay]] and Denise Nolan Cascino were the film's producers, and [[Ben Stiller]] and [[Stuart Cornfeld]] were the executive producers.<ref name="bamkapow"/> [[Justin Theroux]] and [[Guillermo del Toro]] worked as creative consultants on the film. Del Toro only came onboard three weeks before the end of production,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indielondon.co.uk/Film-Review/megamind-tom-mcgrath-interview|title=IndieLondon: Megamind - Tom McGrath interview|publisher=Your London Reviews|author=Carnevale, Rob|accessdate=March 23, 2012}}</ref> but went on to have a more substantial role in subsequent [[DreamWorks Animation]] films. The opening of the film, where Megamind is falling to his apparent death, was del Toro's idea.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cinemablend.com/new/Exclusive-Interview-Megamind-Director-Tom-McGrath-21539.html|title=Exclusive Interview: Megamind Director Tom McGrath|publisher=CinemaBlend.com|author=Eisenberg, Eric|date=November 3, 2010|accessdate=March 23, 2012}}</ref>
==Music== {{Main|Megamind: Music from the Motion Picture}} '''''Megamind: Music from the Motion Picture''''' is a soundtrack to the film of the same name, composed by [[Hans Zimmer]] and [[Lorne Balfe]], and released on November 2, 2010 by [[Lakeshore Records]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Jagernauth |first=Kevin |title='Megamind' Soundtrack Features Elvis Presley, George Thorogood & Lots Of Hans Zimmer |url=http://blogs.indiewire.com/theplaylist/megamind_soundtrack_features_elvis_presley_george_thorogood_lots_of_hans_zi |accessdate=April 20, 2012 |newspaper=The Playlist |date=October 22, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Megamind |url=http://www.lakeshore-records.com/megamind |publisher=Lakeshore Records |accessdate=April 20, 2012}}</ref>
==Release== ''Megamind'' premiered on October 28, 2010, in Russia, and was theatrically released in the United States on November 5, 2010.<ref>{{cite news|title=Shrek Forever After Becomes DreamWorks Animation's Biggest International Release Ever |url=http://ir.dreamworksanimation.com/releasedetail.cfm?ReleaseID=540691 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20131210124919/http://ir.dreamworksanimation.com/releasedetail.cfm?ReleaseID=540691 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=December 10, 2013 |accessdate=December 10, 2013 |newspaper=DreamWorks Animation |date=September 7, 2010 |author=DreamWorks Animation }}</ref> It was supposed to be released in Japan on March 12, 2011, but because of the [[2011 Tohoku earthquake and tsunami|earthquake and tsunami]] a day before, the Japanese release was cancelled.<ref>{{cite news|last=Segers|first=Segers|title=''Tangled'', ''Megamind'' Releases in Limbo in Japan|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/tangled-megamind-releases-limbo-japan-166974|accessdate=October 13, 2012|newspaper=The Hollywood Reporter|date=November 3, 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110313041947/http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/tangled-megamind-releases-limbo-japan-166974|archivedate=March 13, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Segers|first=Frank|title=Japan’s Earthquake Pushes Down International Box Office 60% From Last Year|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/japan-s-earthquake-crushes-international-167167|accessdate=December 9, 2013|newspaper=The Hollywood Reporter|date=March 13, 2011|quote=Although DreamWorks Animation’s Megamind had been listed on some overseas schedules as a March 12 opener in Japan, distributor Paramount said the film did not premier in the market on the weekend. Furthermore, said Andrew Cripps, president of Paramount Pictures Int’l., the 3D animation title --winding an overseas campaign begun in October of 2010 -- "will not release there."}}</ref>
===Marketing=== ''Megamind'' was promoted at the 2010 [[San Diego Comic-Con International]], with Tom McGrath, Tina Fey, Jonah Hill, and Will Ferrell, who was dressed as Megamind.<ref>{{cite news|last=Y Thompson|first=Luke|title=Comic-Con #3: The ‘Megamind’ Panel|url=http://www.deadline.com/2010/07/comic-con-3-the-megamind-panel/|accessdate=April 21, 2012|newspaper=Deadline|date=July 22, 2010}}</ref>
===Home media=== ''Megamind'' was released on both [[Blu-ray Disc]] and DVD on February 25, 2011, accompanied with an all-new short titled ''[[Megamind: The Button of Doom]]''.<ref>{{cite news | last=Calonge | first=Juan | url=http://www.blu-ray.com/news/?id=5681 | title=Megamind Blu-ray Announced | publisher=Blu-ray.com | date=January 4, 2011 | accessdate=January 4, 2011}}</ref> ''The Button of Doom'' also had its television premiere on [[Nickelodeon (TV channel)|Nick]], which was aired on February 26, 2011. It was the seventh-best-selling DVD of 2011 with over 3 million units sold.<ref>[http://www.the-numbers.com/dvd/charts/annual/2011.php Top-Selling DVDs of 2011] Retrieved May 3, 2013</ref> The film made a total of $75 million in DVD and Blu-ray sales.<ref>[https://www.the-numbers.com/movie/Megamind#tab=video-sales Megamind (2010)] Retrieved July 18, 2018</ref>
The film was released on [[Blu-ray Disc|Blu-ray 3D]] in March 2011 exclusively as a part of Samsung 3D Starter Kits,<ref>{{cite news|last=Calonge|first=Juan|title=Samsung 3D Starter Kit Now with Megamind 3D Blu-ray (Update)|url=http://www.blu-ray.com/news/?id=5976|accessdate=October 5, 2011|newspaper=Blu-ray.com|date=March 24, 2011}}</ref> and on September 11, 2011, exclusively at Best Buy stores.<ref>{{cite web|last=Peck|first=Aaron|title=Megamind – 3D (Blu-ray)|url=http://bluray.highdefdigest.com/4284/megamind_3d.html|work=High-Def Digest|accessdate=October 5, 2011|date=September 20, 2011}}</ref>
In July 2014, the film's distribution rights were purchased by [[DreamWorks Animation]] from [[Paramount Pictures]] and transferred to [[20th Century Fox]], the rights are now owned by [[Universal Pictures]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Chney|first1=Alexandra|title=DreamWorks Animation Q2 Earnings Fall Short of Estimates, SEC Investigation Revealed|url=https://variety.com/2014/biz/news/dreamworks-animation-q2-earnings-fall-short-of-estimates-1201271262/|accessdate=July 30, 2014|work=Variety|date=July 29, 2014}}</ref>
==Reception==
===Box office=== ''Megamind'' opened to $12.5 million on opening day, and earned $46 million over the three-day weekend, taking the No. 1 spot and averaged $11,668 from around 7,300 screens at 3,944 theaters. The opening was a bit higher than ''[[How to Train Your Dragon (film)|How to Train Your Dragon]]'', which earned $43.7 million back in March 2010. It was the fifth-highest opening for an animated feature in 2010. In its second weekend, it repeated at No. 1 and dropped 37% to $29.1 million for a $7,374 average from 3,949 theaters, and bringing its 10-day cumulative total to $88.8 million. On its third weekend, it fell 45% to $16 million and finished second to ''[[Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows – Part 1]]'', averaging $4,237 from 3,779 theaters. Over Thanksgiving weekend, it held well with just a 22% drop to $12.6 million and slid to third place behind ''Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows – Part 1'' and ''[[Tangled]]'' (it earned $17,304,307 over the five-day Thanksgiving period). Following Thanksgiving, the film fell a sharp 61% in its fifth weekend to $4.9 million and finished in sixth place.
The film closed in theaters on February 24, 2011 (a day before it was released on DVD and Blu-ray), earning $148.4 million in North America, and $173.5 million in other countries, for a worldwide total of $321.9 million.<ref name="Box Office" /> The final gross was on the low end for a DreamWorks Animation film, but was still a box office success since it beat its $130 million budget. It is the sixth-highest-grossing animated film from 2010 worldwide, behind ''[[Toy Story 3]]'' ($1.063 billion), ''[[Shrek Forever After]]'' ($753 million), ''Tangled'' ($591 million), ''[[Despicable Me]]'' ($543 million), and ''How to Train Your Dragon'' ($494 million), the highest-grossing film worldwide in both Ferrell and Fey's careers,<ref>{{cite web|url= http://boxofficemojo.com/people/chart/?view=Actor&id=willferrell.htm|title=Will Ferrell Box Office Results|accessdate=July 6, 2011|work=[[Box Office Mojo]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.boxofficemojo.com/people/chart/?view=Actor&id=tinafey.htm|title=Tina Fey Box Office Results|accessdate=March 30, 2011|work=[[Box Office Mojo]]}}</ref> as well as the fourth-highest-grossing superhero comedy film, behind ''[[Incredibles 2]]'', ''[[The Incredibles]]'' and ''[[Big Hero 6 (film)|Big Hero 6]]''.
===Critical response=== Review aggregation website [[Rotten Tomatoes]] gives a score of 72% based on 176 reviews and an average rating of 6.6 out of 10.<ref name="rt">{{cite web|title=Megamind (2010)|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/megamind/|publisher= [[Flixster]] | work = [[Rotten Tomatoes]]|accessdate=December 25, 2017}}</ref> The site's consensus states the film "regurgitates plot points from earlier animated efforts, and isn't quite as funny as it should be, but a top-shelf voice cast and strong visuals help make ''Megamind'' a pleasant, if unspectacular, diversion."<ref name="rt" /> Another review aggregator, [[Metacritic]], which assigns a [[normalization (statistics)|normalized]] rating out of 100 to reviews from mainstream critics, calculated an average score of 63 based on 33 reviews.<ref>{{cite web|title=Megamind|url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/megamind|publisher= CBS Interactive | work = [[Metacritic]] |accessdate=October 13, 2012}}</ref> Audiences polled by Cinemascore gave ''Megamind'' a grade of "A-" on a scale from A+ to F-.<ref>{{cite news | title = Company Town: 'Megamind' orchestrates a box-office win | date = November 8, 2010 | author = Steven Zeitchik | work = [[Los Angeles Times]] | url = http://articles.latimes.com/2010/nov/08/entertainment/la-et-box-office-20101108 }}</ref>
[[Roger Ebert]] of the ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]'' awarded the film three out of four stars, stating "This set-up is bright and amusing, even if it does feel recycled from bits and pieces of such recent animated landmarks as ''[[The Incredibles]]'' with its superpowers and ''[[Despicable Me]]'' with its villain."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20101103/REVIEWS/101109990 | authorlink = Roger Ebert | last = Ebert | first = Roger | title=Megamind :: rogerebert.com |publisher=[[Sun Times Media Group]] | work=Chicago Sun-Times | date=November 3, 2010}}</ref> Stephen Holden, of ''[[The New York Times]]'', positively wrote in his review, "Visually ''Megamind'' is immaculately sleek and gracefully enhanced by 3-D."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://movies.nytimes.com/2010/11/05/movies/05mega.html?ref=movies&pagewanted=1 | last = Holden | first = Stephen | title=Animated Ambiguity, Featuring a Big Head |work=[[The New York Times Company]] | date=November 4, 2010 | accessdate=November 5, 2010}}</ref> ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' reviewer [[Owen Gleiberman]] graded the film a B+ and wrote, "...too goofy-surreal to pack a lot of emotional punch, but it's antically light on its feet, with 3-D images that have a lustrous, gizmo-mad sci-fi clarity."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20438854,00.html | title=MegaMind Movie Review | last = Glieberman | first = Owen | accessdate=November 5, 2010 | date=November 3, 2010 |work=Entertainment Weekly}}</ref> [[Peter Travers]] of ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' commented, "What this raucous 3D animated fun house lacks in originality (think bastard child of ''The Incredibles'' and ''Despicable Me'') it makes up for in visual and vocal wit."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/movies/reviews/45905/231040 | last = Travers | first = Peter | work=Rolling Stone | publisher=Wenner Media LLC | title=MegaMind Film Review | accessdate=November 6, 2010}}</ref> In a mixed review, Betsy Sharkey of the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' wrote, "Just as Megamind struggles to find his center, at times, so does the film."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/news/la-et-megamind-20101105,0,1617798.story | last = Sharkey | first = Betsy | title=Movie review: 'Megamind' | publisher=Los Angeles Times | date=November 5, 2010 | accessdate=November 7, 2010}}</ref>
The main point of criticism was the unoriginality of the film. [[Michael Phillips (critic)|Michael Phillips]] of the ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'' wrote: "You have seen all this before",<ref>{{cite news | authorlink = Michael Phillips (critic) |last= Phillips|first= Michael|title= Heroes and villains: A wash of color can't perk up tired plot lines|url= http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2010-11-04/entertainment/sc-mov-1102-megamind-20101104_1_megamind-villains-voice |accessdate= August 29, 2012|newspaper=Chicago Tribune|date=November 4, 2010}}</ref> while Justin Chang of ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' said: "Though enlivened by some moderately clever twists on the superhero-movie template, ''Megamind'' never shakes off a feeling of been-there-spoofed-that."<ref>{{cite news|last=Chang|first=Justin|title=Megamind|url= http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117943959 |accessdate= August 29, 2012|newspaper= Variety|date=November 1, 2010}}</ref> Claudia Puig of [[USA Today]] even asked: "Do we really need ''Megamind'' when ''Despicable Me'' is around?".<ref>{{cite news|last=Puig|first=Claudia|title=Villainous hero Megamind: Been there, animated that|url= https://www.usatoday.com/life/movies/reviews/2010-11-05-megamind05_ST_N.htm |accessdate=August 29, 2012|newspaper=USA Today|date=November 6, 2010}}</ref>
===Accolades=== {| class="wikitable" style="margin:auto;" |- style="text-align:center;" ! Award ! Category ! Name ! Outcome |- |[[38th Annie Awards]]<ref>{{cite web|title=38th Annual Annie Nominations |url=http://annieawards.org/consideration_winners38.html |publisher=The Annie Awards |accessdate=September 23, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111217041421/http://www.annieawards.org/consideration_winners38.html |archivedate=December 17, 2011 |df= }}</ref> |[[38th Annie Awards#Animated Effects in an Animated Production|Animated Effects in an Animated Production]] |Krzysztof Rostek |{{Nom}} |- |[[Washington D.C. Area Film Critics Association Awards 2010]]<ref>{{cite news|title=The 2010 WAFCA Award Winners|url=http://www.wafca.com/awards/2010.htm|accessdate=September 23, 2012|newspaper=The Washington DC Area Film Critics Association|date=December 6, 2010}}</ref> |Best Animated Film | |{{Nom}} |- |[[2011 Kids' Choice Awards]]<ref>{{cite news|title=Expect the Unexpected as Jack Black Hosts Nickelodeon's 2011 Kids' Choice Awards Airing Live From Los Angeles on Saturday, April 2, at 8pm ET|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/expect-the-unexpected-as-jack-black-hosts-nickelodeons-2011-kids-choice-awards-airing-live-from-los-angeles-on-saturday-april-2-at-8pm-et-115725019.html|accessdate=September 23, 2012|newspaper=PR Newswire|date=February 10, 2011|author=Nickelodeon}}</ref> |Favorite Buttkicker From An Animated Movie |Will Ferrell |{{Nom}} |- |[[The National Movie Awards]]<ref>{{cite news|title=The King's Speech wins three National Movie Awards|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-13365345|accessdate=September 23, 2012|newspaper=BBC|date=May 11, 2011}}</ref> |Best Animated Movie | |{{Nom}} |- |[[The Comedy Awards]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Nominees|url=http://www.thecomedyawards.com/2011/categories/|publisher=The Comedy Awards|accessdate=September 23, 2012}}</ref> |Best Animated Comedy Movie | |{{Nom}} |}
==Video games== Several [[Megamind (video game)|video game tie-ins]] published by [[THQ]] were released on November 2, 2010 to coincide with the film's release. An [[Xbox 360]] and [[PlayStation 3]] version is titled ''Megamind: Ultimate Showdown'', while the [[Wii]] version is titled ''Megamind: Mega Team Unite'' and the [[PlayStation Portable]] and [[Nintendo DS]] versions are both titled ''Megamind: The Blue Defender''. All three versions of the game have been rated E10+ for fantasy violence by the [[Entertainment Software Rating Board|ESRB]].<ref>[http://www.megamindvideogame.com DreamWorks' Megamind: The Video Games] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101111080414/http://www.megamindvideogame.com/ |date=November 11, 2010 }}. Retrieved December 8, 2010.</ref>
==Comic books== DreamWorks Animation and [[WildStorm]] produced a 32-page full-color comic book titled ''The Reign of Megamind'', which was released in July 2010 exclusively at the [[San Diego Comic-Con International|Comic-Con]] convention.<ref>{{cite news|last=Goellner |first=Caleb |title='The Reign of Megamind' Comic Coming to Comic-Con (Exclusive) |url=http://www.comicsalliance.com/2010/07/16/the-reign-of-megamind-comic-coming-to-comic-con-exclusive/ |accessdate=April 21, 2012 |newspaper=Comics Alliance |date=July 16, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110108043000/http://www.comicsalliance.com/2010/07/16/the-reign-of-megamind-comic-coming-to-comic-con-exclusive/ |archivedate=January 8, 2011 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Full version of the comic is also available on the ''Megamind'' website.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Reign of Megamind|url=http://www.megamind.com/comic/|publisher=[[DreamWorks Animation]]|accessdate=March 18, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121121045624/http://www.megamind.com/comic/|archivedate=November 21, 2012|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
Ape Entertainment released under its Kizoic label five full colour comic books based on the film. A 52-page prequel titled "MEGAMIND: Reign of Megamind" was released in October 2010. It features two stories titled "The Reign of Megamind" and "MINION 2.0". The stories show Megamind and Minion's biggest failures in their attempt to defeat Metro Man. In 2010 and 2011 followed a mini series of four 32-page books. The comic book #1 features story titled "Can I Have This Dance", #2 features "Bad Minion! Bad!", #3 features "Megamutt" and #4 features "A Sidekick's Sidekick".<ref>{{cite web|title=Megamind|url=http://ape-entertainment.com/comics/licensed-properties/megamind/|publisher=Ape Entertainment|accessdate=April 9, 2012}}</ref>
==Possible sequel== In April 2011, DreamWorks Animation's CEO, [[Jeffrey Katzenberg]], commented that the studio did not have plans to produce future movie genre parodies like ''[[Shark Tale]]'', ''[[Monsters vs. Aliens]]'', and ''Megamind'', saying that these films "all shared an approach and tone and idea of parody, and did not travel well internationally. We don't have anything like that coming on our schedule now."<ref>{{cite news|last=Lieberman|first=David|title=DreamWorks Animation Pins Hopes On ‘Kung Fu Panda 2′ After 1Q Earnings Fall Short|url=http://www.deadline.com/2011/04/dreamworks-pins-hopes-on-kung-fu-panda-2-after-first-quarter-earnings-fall-short/|accessdate=September 17, 2012|newspaper=Deadline|date=April 26, 2011}}</ref>

{{short description|Digital locker for movies}} {{Use mdy dates|date=October 2017}} {{infobox brand | name = Movies Anywhere, LLC.{{cite web|url=https://moviesanywhere.com/privacy-policy|title=Movies Anywhere Privacy Policy - Movies Anywhere|website=moviesanywhere.com}} | former_name = Disney Movies Anywhere | logo = [[File:MoviesAnywhereLogo.png]] | logo_caption = | type = [[Digital locker|Digital rights locker service]], [[video on demand]] |currentowner = [[Walt Disney Direct-to-Consumer and International]] | introduced = {{start date and age|2014|2|10}} (as Disney Movies Anywhere)
{{start date and age|2017|10|12}} (as Movies Anywhere) | related = Disney Movie Rewards | markets = [[United States ]] (Web, iOS, tvOS, Android, Android TV, Kindle, Fire TV, Roku) | tagline = Your Movies, Together at Last. | website = {{Official site|https://www.moviesanywhere.com}} }} '''Movies Anywhere''' is a United States-exclusive [[Cloud computing|cloud-based]] [[digital locker]] and [[over-the-top content|over-the-top streaming]] platform operated by [[The Walt Disney Company]].{{cite news|last1=Prange|first1=Stephanie|title=Movies Anywhere App Launches With Joint Studio Backing|url=https://variety.com/2017/digital/news/movies-anywhere-launches-with-joint-studio-backing-1202587915/|accessdate=October 12, 2017|work=Variety|date=October 11, 2017}} The service allows users to [[Streaming media|stream]] and download purchased films, including [[digital copy|digital copies]] redeemed from codes found in [[home video]] releases as well as digital purchases from participating services. The platform provides content from [[Walt Disney Studios (division)|Walt Disney Studios]], [[Universal Pictures]], [[20th Century Fox]], [[Warner Bros.]] and [[Sony Pictures]].{{cite news|last1=Hayes|first1=Dade|title=Four Major Studios Join U.S. Launch Of Disney’s Movies Anywhere Digital Service|url=http://deadline.com/2017/10/four-major-studios-join-disney-movies-anywhere-digital-service-1202186760/|accessdate=October 12, 2017|work=Deadline.com|date=October 11, 2017}} The system utilizes an internal platform known as '''KeyChest''', which synchronizes content licenses from digital distribution platforms linked to a central user account. Movies Anywhere was first launched on February 10, 2014 as '''Disney Movies Anywhere''' (DMA) with content from [[Walt Disney Pictures|Disney]], [[Pixar]], [[Marvel Studios|Marvel]], and ''[[Star Wars]]''-branded films on [[iOS]] with [[iTunes Store]] integration; the service has since been extended to other platforms and storefronts, including [[Amazon Video]], [[Google Play]], [[Vudu]], [[Fandango_(company)#FandangoNow|FandangoNow]],{{cite news|last1=Spangler|first1=Todd|title=Fandango Joins Disney-Owned Movies Anywhere|url=https://variety.com/2018/digital/news/fandango-movies-anywhere-disney-1202724990/|accessdate=June 17, 2018|work=Variety.com|date=March 12, 2018}} and [[Microsoft Movies & TV]]. On October 12, 2017, DMA was relaunched as Movies Anywhere, with other studios joining Disney in offering their film titles through the platform. Movies Anywhere is a competitor to the [[UltraViolet (system)|UltraViolet]] platform that was deployed by other major film studios (though the latter is declining as most of those studios move to Movies Anywhere); Disney declined to back the platform, in favor of promoting KeyChest as an alternative. == History == In 2009, Disney unveiled a rights synchronization platform known as KeyChest, which would allow content purchases via digital distribution platforms to be queried and used to build a centralized library. The company explained that this system would allow "persistent" access to purchased content across multiple digital platforms, including television set-top boxes and mobiles.{{Cite news|url=https://www.engadget.com/2014/02/25/disney-movies-anywhere/|title=Disney Movies Anywhere service launches with an unprecedented link to iTunes|work=Engadget|access-date=October 12, 2017|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.engadget.com/2010/01/10/disneys-keychest-is-not-drm/|title=Disney's KeyChest is not DRM|work=Engadget|access-date=October 12, 2017|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=http://mashable.com/2009/10/21/disney-going-digital/|title=Disney's Going Digital: Buy Once, Watch Anywhere|last=Warren|first=Christina|work=Mashable|access-date=October 12, 2017|language=en}}{{Citation|last=Healey|first=Jon|title=Disney offers KeyChest, but where is the KeyMaster?|date=January 5, 2010|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/technology/2010/01/disney-keychest-drm-dece.html|work=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=December 8, 2011}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748703816204574485650026945222|title=Disney Touts a Way to Ditch the DVD|last=Smith|first=Ethan|website=WSJ|access-date=October 16, 2017}}.The platform was viewed as being a competitor to [[UltraViolet (system)|UltraViolet]], a competing concept developed by [[Digital Entertainment Content Ecosystem|DECE]], a consortium containing all other [[Major film studio|major U.S. film studios]] but Disney. Disney Movies Anywhere originally launched on February 10, 2014, as an [[iOS]] app that allows users to link Disney films purchased on [[iTunes Store]] into a unified library with digital copies of Disney films purchased on physical media, so that they can be streamed or downloaded. The integration is achieved by linking a user's [[Apple ID]] with a Disney account. The app also allows users to browse through a catalog of Disney films available on iTunes Store, access supplemental content such as interviews and behind-the-scenes footage, and participate in the Disney Movie Rewards program. Walt Disney Studios CTO Jamie Voris explained that the app was designed to provide a "rich, interactive experience" around its content as an alternative to "utilitarian" online stores, and that Disney planned to seek additional retail partners for the service in the future.{{Cite news|url=https://techcrunch.com/2014/02/25/disney-movies-anywhere/|title=Disney Launches Disney Movies Anywhere, An iTunes-Integrated App Where Fans Can Build Their Movie Library|last=Ha|first=Anthony|work=TechCrunch|access-date=October 12, 2017|language=en}} In November 2014, support for [[Google Play Movies & TV]] and [[Vudu]] was added.{{Cite news|url=https://variety.com/2014/digital/news/walmarts-vudu-joins-disney-movies-anywhere-1201356728/|title=Walmart’s Vudu Joins Disney Movies Anywhere|last=Graser|first=Marc|date=November 14, 2014|work=Variety|access-date=October 12, 2017|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=https://techcrunch.com/2014/11/03/disney-and-google-partner-up-for-disney-movies-anywhere-access-on-google-play/|title=Disney And Google Partner Up For Disney Movies Anywhere Access On Google Play|last=Buhr|first=Sarah|work=TechCrunch|access-date=October 12, 2017|language=en}} In September 2015, support for [[Amazon Video]] and [[Microsoft Movies & TV]] was added, and DMA apps for [[Android TV]] and [[Roku]] were also released.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theverge.com/2015/9/8/9276525/disney-movies-anywhere-now-available-amazon-microsoft|title=Disney's fantastic cloud movie locker now works with Amazon, Microsoft video apps|work=The Verge|access-date=October 12, 2017}} In August 2016, [[Verizon Fios]] became the first television provider to integrate with DMA, allowing purchases through Fios On Demand to be synced into DMA libraries.{{Cite web|url=http://www.multichannel.com/news/content/verizon-fios-first-mvpd-connect-disney-movies-anywhere/407221|title=Verizon Fios First MVPD to Connect to Disney Movies Anywhere|website=Multichannel News|language=en|access-date=October 16, 2017}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.bizjournals.com/losangeles/news/2016/08/24/verizon-fios-joins-disney-movies-anywhere.html|title= Verizon Fios joins Disney Movies Anywhere platform|website=L.A. Biz|access-date=October 16, 2017}} In September 2017, DMA ceased support for Microsoft Movies & TV, with future purchases no longer automatically accessible through the linked library {{Cite news|url=https://www.engadget.com/2017/09/08/disney-movies-anywhere-drops-microsoft/|title=Disney Movies Anywhere drops Microsoft as a partner|work=Engadget|access-date=October 12, 2017|language=en-US}} however in August 2018 support for the service provider was officially restored under Movies Anywhere. On October 10, 2017, it was reported that the DMA platform would expand to include content from non-Disney studios under the name Movies Anywhere, with [[20th Century Fox]], [[Sony Pictures]], [[Universal Pictures]], and [[Warner Bros.]] serving as initial partners, and [[Lionsgate]] and [[Paramount Pictures]] expressing interest.{{Cite news|url=https://variety.com/2017/digital/news/disney-movies-anywhere-adds-fox-wb-universal-report-1202585994/|title=Disney Movies Anywhere Adds Fox, WB, Universal (Report)|last=Gruenwedel|first=Erik|date=October 10, 2017|work=Variety|access-date=October 12, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} It would also include titles from Disney's [[Touchstone Pictures]] and [[Hollywood Pictures]] banners that were previously unavailable on DMA. The DMA platform was relaunched on October 12, 2017. ''[[The Verge]]'' felt that the new platform could be used to replace the commercially-unsuccessful UltraViolet platform (which Disney did not support).{{Cite news|url=https://www.theverge.com/2017/10/12/16462824/movies-anywhere-digital-movie-locker-disney-warner-bros-universal-twentieth-century-fox-sony|title=Hollywood studios join Disney to launch Movies Anywhere digital locker service|work=The Verge|access-date=October 12, 2017}} Just two months after launch, at the January 2018 [[Consumer Electronics Show]] in Las Vegas, GM Karin Gilford announced that consumers’ accounts have accumulated nearly 80 million movies.{{cite news|last1=Arnold|first1=Thomas|title=Betting on Movies Anywhere|url=https://www.mediaplaynews.com/betting-on-movies-anywhere/|accessdate=April 27, 2018|work=Media Play News|date=February 25, 2018}} That same month, Movies Anywhere was picked the 2018 winner of the inaugural [[Home Media Magazine|Media Play News]] Fast Forward Awards, honoring people, technologies, organizations, products or services that move the home entertainment industry forward. Support for [[Fandango_(company)#FandangoNOW|FandangoNOW]] was added on March 13, 2018,{{cite news|last1=England|first1=Rachel|title=Movies Anywhere includes your FandangoNOW flicks|url=https://www.engadget.com/2018/03/13/movies-anywhere-includes-your-fandangonow-flicks/|work=Engadget|date=March 13, 2018}} with talks also resuming between Movies Anywhere and Microsoft Movies & TV.{{cite web |last1=Thorp-Lancaster |first1=Dan |title=Microsoft 'in discussions' about joining Movies Anywhere |url=https://www.windowscentral.com/microsoft-discussions-about-joining-movies-anywhere |website=Windows Central |publisher=Mobile Nations |accessdate=July 19, 2018 |date=March 14, 2018}} By then, there were more than 100 million movies in consumer accounts.{{cite news|url=https://www.mediaplaynews.com/movies-anywhere-adds-fandangonow/|title=Movies Anywhere Adds FandangoNow|newspaper=Media Play News|publisher=[[JCH Media Inc.]]|accessdate=April 27, 2018}} On August 6, 2018, it was announced that [[Microsoft Movies & TV]] would be rejoining the Movies Anywhere service. By then, the number of movies in customer accounts had grown to more than 135 million.{{cite news|last1=Moon|first1=Tim|title=Microsoft Movies & TV rejoins Movies Anywhere|url=https://www.neowin.net/news/microsoft-movies--tv-rejoins-movies-anywhere|work=Neowin|date=August 6, 2018}}{{cite news|last1=Latchem|first1=John|title=Microsoft Joins Movies Anywhere Platform|url=https://www.mediaplaynews.com/microsoft-joins-movies-anywhere-platform/|newspaper=Media Play News|publisher=[[JCH Media Inc.]]|accessdate=August 6, 2018}} On November 9, the General Manager of Movies Anywhere announced that the service had 6 million users. {{cite web |url=https://variety.com/2018/digital/news/movies-anywhere-disney-6-million-app-downloads-1203023433/ |website=Variety}} == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * {{official website}} {{Disney}} {{Video digital distribution platforms}} [[Category:Video on demand services]] [[Category:Disney technology]] [[Category:Internet properties established in 2014]] [[Category:Entertainment websites]] [[Category:Digital rights management systems]]

The notion of '''musical similarity''' is particularly complex because there are numerous dimensions of similarity. If similarity takes place between different fragments from one musical piece, a musical similarity implies a [[repetition (music)|repetition]] of the first occurring fragment. As well, eventually, the similarity does not occur by direct repetition, but by presenting in two (or more) set of relations, some common values or patterns. Objective musical similarity can be based on musical features such as:
Pitched parameters * [[Pitch (music)|Pitch]] interval similarity * [[Melody|Melodic]] similarity<ref>Greg Aloupis, Thomas Fevens, [[Stefan Langerman]], Tomomi Matsui, Antonio Mesa, Yurai Nunez, and David Rappaport, and Godfried T. Toussaint, "Algorithms for computing geometric measures of melodic similarity," ''Computer Music Journal'', Vol. 30, No. 3, Fall 2006, pp. 67–76.</ref> * [[Modulation (music)|Modulation]] pattern similarity * [[Timbre|Timbral]] similarity
Non-pitched parameters * [[Meter (music)|Metrical]] structure similarity * [[Rhythm]]ic pattern similarity<ref>Godfried T. Toussaint, "A comparison of rhythmic dissimilarity measures," ''FORMA'', Vol. 21, No. 2, 2006, pp. 129–149.</ref> * [[Section (music)|Section]] structure similarity
Semiotic parameters * [[Modality (semiotics)|Modality]] structure similarity * [[Extension (semantics)|Extension]]al similarity * [[Intension]]al similarity
Nevertheless, similarity can be based also on less objective features such as musical genre, personal history, social context (e.g. music from the 1960s), and a priori knowledge.
==Applications== Automatic methods of musical similarity detection based on [[data mining]] and [[co-occurrence]] analysis has been developed in order to classify music titles for electronic music distribution.<ref>[[François Pachet]], Geert Westermann, Damien Laigre, [http://www.csl.sony.fr/downloads/papers/2001/pachet01c.pdf Musical Data Mining for Electronic Music Distribution]. Proceedings of the 1st WedelMusic Conference, pp. 101-106, Firenze, Italy, 2001.</ref>
==References== <references/>
{{DEFAULTSORT:Musical Similarity}} [[Category:Music theory]] {{Music-theory-stub}}

TIK Films (2) | distributor = [[Summit Entertainment]] | released = 2013-present | country = United States | language = English | budget = $165 million | gross = $686.6 million }} '''''Now You See Me''''' is a [[film series|series]] of [[heist film|heist]] [[thriller film]]s written by [[Ed Solomon]], [[Boaz Yakin]], and Edward Ricourt. They focus on the actions of a team of illusionists named "The Four Horsemen" who pull off near impossible heists. The series features an ensemble cast including [[Jesse Eisenberg]], [[Mark Ruffalo]], [[Woody Harrelson]], [[Isla Fisher]], [[Dave Franco]], [[Michael Caine]], [[Lizzy Caplan]], and [[Morgan Freeman]]. The [[Now You See Me (film)|first film]] was released in 2013, while [[Now You See Me 2|the second]] was released in 2016, and a third film is currently in development and set to be released in 2019. The series has received mixed reviews from critics and audiences and grossed nearly $700 million worldwide. ==Films== ===''Now You See Me'' (2013)=== {{main|Now You See Me (film)}} An FBI agent ([[Mark Ruffalo]]), and an Interpol Detective, track a team of illusionists, who pull off bank heists during their performances, and reward their audiences with the money. ===''Now You See Me 2'' (2016)=== {{main|Now You See Me 2}} The Four Horsemen resurface, and are forcibly recruited by a tech genius to pull off an almost impossible heist. ===''Now You See Me 3'' (TBA)=== {{main|Now You See Me 2#Future}} In May 2015, [[Lionsgate]] CEO [[Jon Feltheimer]] announced that they had indeed "already begun early planning" for ''Now You See Me 3''.{{cite web|last=McNary|first=Dave|title='Now You See Me 3' in the Works at Lionsgate |url=https://variety.com/2015/film/news/now-you-see-me-3-in-the-works-at-lionsgate-1201503265/|accessdate=May 22, 2015|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=May 22, 2015}} It was later confirmed that [[Lizzy Caplan]] will be reprising the role of Lula May, and that a new cast member, [[Benedict Cumberbatch]], will be joining the cast. It was also confirmed that [[Isla Fisher]] will unlikely return to the series as Henley Reeves, after her absence from the second film.{{cite web|url=http://www.parentherald.com/articles/91553/20161202/now-you-see-me-3-release-date-benedict-cumberbatch-movie-sequels.htm|title='Now You See Me 3' Release Date Confirmed As Production Rolls In Plus A New Cast Member To Join The Gang|last=Lawrence|first=Sophie|work=Parent Herald|date=December 2, 2016|accessdate=December 3, 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://www.opptrends.com/2017/02/now-see-3-release-date-new-cast-member/|title=Now You See Me 3 Release Date & A New Cast Member|last=Stojilović|first=Milena|work=OppTrends|date=February 24, 2017|accessdate=February 24, 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.opptrends.com/2017/02/now-see-3-isla-fisher-replaced-another-actress/|title=Now You See Me 3 Isla Fisher Replaced By Another Actress|last=Stojilović|first=Milena|work=OppTrends|date=February 25, 2017|accessdate=February 25, 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.christianpost.com/news/now-you-see-me-3-release-date-cast-isla-fisher-officially-out-benedict-cumberbatch-in-176815/|title='Now You See Me 3' Release Date, Cast News: Isla Fisher Officially Out, Benedict Cumbercatch In?|last=Espiritu|first=Emmanuelle|work=The Christian Post|date=March 7, 2017|accessdate=March 9, 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.travelerstoday.com/articles/44225/20170331/now-see-3-update-benedict-cumberbatch-reportedly-joins-cast.htm|title='Now You See Me 3' Update: Benedict Cumberbatch Reportedly Joins Cast|last=Jabin|first=Bhatz|work=Travelers Today|date=March 31, 2017|accessdate=April 1, 2017}} In December 2016, it was announced that writers Neil Widener and Gavin James were hired to write the screenplay.{{cite web|url=http://wegotthiscovered.com/movies/now-you-see-me-3-lands-writers/|title=Now You See Me 3 Lands Writers|date=December 14, 2016}} ==Spin-off== {{main|Now You See Me 2#Future}} In July 2016, ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' reported that [[Lionsgate]] was to make a ''Now You See Me'' spin-off with a primarily Chinese cast, starring [[Jay Chou]] as Li, his character from ''Now You See Me 2''.{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/lionsgate-make-chinese-spinoff-you-911469|title=Lionsgate to Make Chinese Spinoff of 'Now You See Me' (Exclusive)|last=Brzeski|first=Patrick|work=The Hollywood Reporter|date=July 15, 2016|accessdate=February 11, 2017}} ==Cast== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center; width:99%;" |- !
