revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2014}} {{Use British English|date=May 2014}} '''Peter Eldin''' (born 1939) is a British author and [[Magic (illusion)|magician]]. He has written almost two hundred books; most of them are non-fiction for young people.<ref>Vang, Maikue. Something About the Author. [http://galenet.galegroup.com/servlet/eBooks?ste=22&docNum=CX3433399999&q=norm94900 Facts and Pictures About Authors and Illustrators of Books for Young People Volume 154]. Detroit, Mich: Gale, 2005.</ref> According to [[WorldCat]] there are "132 works in 188 publications in 12 languages and 8,912 library holdings."<ref>{{cite web|title=Eldin, Peter|url=http://www.worldcat.org/wcidentities/viaf-35050257|work=WorldCat|accessdate=12 October 2013}}</ref> He writes mainly on factual material, fun (puzzles, quizzes, jokes, and games) and magic for children, and has also edited magic magazines ''The Magic Circular'' and ''Abracadabra'', and written scripts for TV shows including ''[[The Weakest Link]]''.<ref>"Children's Writer At School", Derby Evening Telegraph, 18 March 2003, p 9 (via Nexis UK)</ref><ref>T Shaw, "Time for a good book", Telegraph, 20 January 1987 (via Nexis UK).</ref><ref name="daigneault"/>
==Books for children== He is best known for the series of humorous instructional books for children such as ''The Trickster's Handbook'' (1976), ''The Secret Agent's Handbook'' (1977) and ''The Whizzkid's Handbook'' (1979), full of tricks, games, puzzles, and advice, with illustrations by Roger Smith.<ref>{{cite web|title=Peter Eldin Biography at JRank|url=http://biography.jrank.org/pages/918/Eldin-Peter-1939.html|accessdate=17 June 2015}}</ref> The following gives a brief flavour of these works: "tell your friends you can kiss a book 'inside and outside' without opening it - then prove it by kissing the book while standing outdoors ... and then indoors. Something semiserious? Baffle your buddies with vanishing water or instant indoor rainbows."<ref>W E Butterworth IV, "Books for all topics", ''[[Boys' Life]]'', November 1991, p16</ref> The series was adapted for television in 1980 as ''The Whizzkids Guide'' starring [[Kenneth Williams]], [[Rita Webb]] and [[Arthur Mullard]] as overgrown schoolchildren.<ref>{{cite web|title=Whizzkids Guide|url=http://ftvdb.bfi.org.uk/sift/title/397106|work=Film & TV Database|publisher=British Film Database|accessdate=12 October 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Whizzkid's Guide|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0081962/|work=IMDb|accessdate=12 October 2013}}</ref><ref>Christopher Stevens ''Kenneth Williams: Born Brilliant'', Hachette UK, 2010</ref> Williams said "the script is full of corny gags which actually make me laugh".<ref>Kenneth Williams, ''The Kenneth Williams Diaries'', ed Russell Davies, HarperCollins UK, 1994</ref>
School Library Journal called ''The Magic Handbook'' "an excellent standard source for magical tricks and advice for most children's library collections for many years to come."<ref>Craighton Hippenhammer, "Review: The Magic Handbook (Book)". School Library Journal; Aug86, Vol. 32 Issue 10, p91.</ref> His book ''Magic'' (1998) has also received praise as an informative history of magic.<ref name=daigneault>Daigneault, Audrey I., "Reference books & nonfiction series", Library Talk, 1043237X, Mar/Apr98, Vol. 11, Issue 2.</ref> ''The Spookster's Handbook'' (CIP Sterling, 1989) is "an entertaining little gem that's chock-full of zany ideas for Halloween", including haunted house ideas, optical illusions, tricks, and riddles, aimed at kids, parents, teachers, and group leaders.<ref>Chamberlin, Leslie, "Review: The Spookster's Handbook (Book)". School Library Journal; Mar90, Vol. 36 Issue 3, p226</ref>
==Magic== In addition to writing several books on [[Magic (illusion)|magic]] (illusionism), he is also an honorary member of the magicians' organisation the [[The Magic Circle (organisation)|Magic Circle]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Honorary Members|url=http://www.themagiccircle.co.uk/about-the-club/awards/560-Honorary-Members|work=The Magic Circle|accessdate=11 April 2012}}</ref> He was involved in curating the Magic Circle's museum in the 1970s and edited the Circle's magazine ''The Magic Circular'' from 1990-1998.<ref>Eddie Dawes, "From Pillar To Post", in ''Circle Without End: The Magic Circle 1905-2005'', ed Edwin A Dawes and Michael Bailey, Jeremy Mills, 2005, p54, pp99–103</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Eldin, Peter}} [[Category:1939 births]] [[Category:British writers]] [[Category:British magicians]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:British non-fiction writers]] [[Category:British male writers]] [[Category:Historians of magic]]

page.title: Professor Layton and the Last Specter

revision.text:
{{Good Article}} {{Use mdy dates|date=October 2012}} {{Infobox video game | title = Professor Layton and the Last Specter | image = Last specter box.png | caption = North American box art. Characters, from left to right: Luke Triton, Hershel Layton, and Emmy Altava | developer = [[Level-5 (company)|Level-5]] | publisher = {{vgrelease|JP|Level-5|WW|Nintendo}} | director = Usuke Kumagai | producer = [[Akihiro Hino]] | composer = [[Tomohito Nishiura]] | engine = | series = ''[[Professor Layton]]'' | released = {{vgrelease|JP|November 26, 2009|NA|October 17, 2011<ref name="1upreview"/>|EU|November 25, 2011<ref name="eu name"/>|AUS|December 1, 2011<ref name="noaurelease">{{cite web|url=https://www.nintendo.com.au/index.php?action%3Dnews%26nid%3D1338 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=November 12, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120401091956/http://www.nintendo.com.au/index.php?action=news&nid=1338 |archivedate=April 1, 2012 }}</ref>}} | genre = [[Puzzle video game|Puzzle]], [[Adventure game|Adventure]] | modes = [[Single-player]] | platforms = [[Nintendo DS]] }} '''''Professor Layton and the Last Specter''''',{{efn|Known in Japan as {{nihongo|'''''Reiton-kyōju to Majin no Fue'''''|レイトン教授と魔神の笛|lit. ''Professor Layton and the Specter's Flute''}}<!-- See [[WP:JFN]] -->}} known in Europe as '''''Professor Layton and the Spectre's Call''''', is a [[Puzzle video game|puzzle]] [[Adventure game|adventure]] video game produced by [[Level-5 (company)|Level-5]] for the [[Nintendo DS]] [[handheld game console]]. ''Last Specter'' is the fourth game in the [[Professor Layton|''Professor Layton'' series]], and is a prequel that takes place three years before the first trilogy, detailing how [[Professor Hershel Layton|Professor Layton]] met his apprentice, [[List of Professor Layton characters#Luke Triton|Luke Triton]] and introducing Layton's assistant [[List of Professor Layton characters#Emmy Altava|Emmy Altava]].
''Professor Layton and the Last Specter'' also includes an additional [[role-playing game]] entitled ''Professor Layton's London Life'', available from the start of the game. ''London Life'', in which players interact with various characters from the series in a town called "Little London", was advertised as having over 100 hours of content. ''London Life'' was removed from the European versions of the game because the translation of texts would have significantly delayed the game's release.
The game was released during 2009 in Japan, and was the highest-selling game there during the week of its release. It saw release in [[North American]] and [[PAL region]]s during 2011.
==Gameplay== ''Professor Layton and the Last Specter'' is a puzzle game presented in the style of an adventure game. The player controls the actions of a group of three protagonists as they move about a village called Misthallery: Professor Hershel Layton, his assistant [[List of Professor Layton characters#Emmy Altava|Emmy Altava]], and a young boy named Luke Triton. While in the village, the three of them are presented with several mysteries that are solved as the plot progresses. Misthallery is divided into several sections, although many require the plot to progress to a certain point before they can be accessed. In order to move about Misthallery, players tap a shoe-shaped [[computer icon|icon]] on the bottom-right corner of the [[touch screen]], and then the arrow representing the direction of the path they wish to take.<ref name="lsmanualp11">{{cite book | title = Professor Layton and the Last Specter Instruction Booklet | section = Exploring | publisher = [[Nintendo of America]] | date = October 17, 2011 | quote = First, tap the shoe icon. Then tap an arrow or a hand icon to move. |page = 11}}</ref> While in Misthallery, the player is capable of tapping anywhere on the bottom screen of the Nintendo DS system to investigate objects and reveal bits of dialogue, hint coins, collectible items, or hidden puzzles.<ref name="ignreviewls">{{cite web | last = Drake | first = Audrey | url = http://www.ign.com/articles/2011/10/18/professor-layton-and-the-last-specter-review | title = Professor Layton and the Last Specter Review | publisher = [[IGN]] | date = October 17, 2011 | accessdate = April 11, 2016}}</ref> Likewise, if a [[non-player character]] is visible on the screen, they can be tapped to initiate a conversation.<ref name="lsmanualp12">{{cite book | title = Professor Layton and the Last Specter Instruction Booklet | section = Talking to People | publisher = Nintendo of America | date = October 17, 2011 | quote = Tap a character on the Touch Screen to interact with him/her. |page = 12}}</ref>
===Puzzles=== [[File:Last Specter Puzzle.png|thumb|right|180px|Puzzle [[interface (computing)|interface]] in ''Professor Layton and the Last Specter''. The puzzle is solved via input from the bottom touch screen, while instructions are provided on the top.]]Initiating a conversation or investigating an object in the main game will often lead to the player being asked to solve a puzzle.<ref name="lsmanualp13b">{{cite book | title = Professor Layton and the Last Specter Instruction Booklet | section = Solving Puzzles | publisher = Nintendo of America | date = October 17, 2011| quote = It will be important to solve as many puzzles as possible in order to progress through the story! Talk to people and search the surrounding area for puzzles. |page = 13}}</ref> If the plot progresses to a point at which a puzzle can no longer be accessed, it will be retrieved by a character named Keats the Cat for later solving.<ref name="noegameplay"/> There are over 170 puzzles in the game,<ref name="noewhatsnew">{{cite web | url = https://www.nintendo.co.uk/NOE/en_GB/games/ms/plsc/whatsnew.html | title = Professor Layton and the Spectre's Call – What's New | publisher = Nintendo of Europe | work = Professor Layton and the Spectre's Call – Official Website | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/639JCjpHl?url=http://www.nintendo.co.uk/NOE/en_GB/games/ms/plsc/whatsnew.html | archivedate = November 12, 2011 | deadurl = yes| accessdate = November 12, 2011}}</ref> including [[brain teaser]]s, [[sliding puzzle]]s, [[logic puzzle]]s, [[peg solitaire]], and several other varieties. When a puzzle begins, the player is briefly presented with the puzzle's name, number, and value in "Picarats", the game's system of [[Score (game)#Video games|point]]s as well as an estimation of the puzzle's difficulty.<ref name="noegameplay"/> These points are not used during the main game, but if a player collects enough of these Picarats, they gain access to bonuses accessible from the main menu.<ref name="noegameplay"/>
After this first screen, players are taken the main puzzle solving interface, which provides instructions for the current puzzle on the top screen while allowing the player to interact directly with the touch screen in order to solve the puzzle. The player has an infinite amount of time to complete each puzzle, and they have access to an in-game [[Notebook|memo pad]] function to aid them in solving each puzzle. If they do not wish to solve the puzzle at the time, they can hit the button labelled "Quit" in order to exit the interface without losing any Picarats.<ref name="noegameplay"/> Additionally, all puzzles have three hints available that can be purchased with tokens called "hint coins". If a player needs more help, they can also purchase a fourth "super hint", a more detailed hint that costs two hint coins.<ref name="noeparents"/><ref name="lsmanualp14a">{{cite book | title = Professor Layton and the Last Specter Instruction Booklet| section = Solving Puzzles | publisher = Nintendo of America | date = October 17, 2011 | quote = There are four hints for each puzzle. The first three hints cost one coin each, but the Super Hint costs two hint coins. There are a limited number of hint coins in the game, so use them sparingly! |page = 14}}</ref> However, there are a limited amount of hint coins, and the game recommends they be used wisely.<ref name="lsmanualp14a"/> The player starts with ten hint coins, but more can be obtained by thorough investigation of the village.<ref name="lsgameprorev">{{cite web | last = Haywald | first = Justin | url = http://www.gamepro.com/article/reviews/224025/review-professor-layton-and-the-last-specter-ds | title = Review: Professor Layton and the Last Specter (DS) | publisher = ''[[GamePro]]'' | date = October 18, 2011 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20111020192500/http://www.gamepro.com/article/reviews/224025/review-professor-layton-and-the-last-specter-ds | archivedate = October 20, 2011 | deadurl = yes | accessdate = April 11, 2016}}</ref>
In order to solve a puzzle, the player must input an answer on the bottom screen. Sometimes, this will involve tapping a button labelled "Input Answer" and writing a word or number that solves the given puzzle. Other times, they might be asked to circle an answer or tap an area on the touch screen, and then hit "Submit". Still others are solved automatically once the player finds the solution by interacting with objects on the bottom screen.<ref name="lsmanualp14b">{{cite book | title = Professor Layton and the Last Specter Instruction Booklet | section = Solving Puzzles | publisher = Nintendo of America | date = October 17, 2011 | quote = Some puzzles will end automatically when you've arrived at the right answer, and others require you to submit your answer manually. |page = 14}}</ref> If the player has made a mistake in solving a puzzle, they can hit the button labelled "Restart" to reset the puzzle. Deducted Picarats and purchased hints are not reset if a puzzle is restarted. If the player submits an incorrect answer, they will be asked to repeat the puzzle, and a varying amount of Picarats will be deducted from the maximum possible for that puzzle.<ref name="ignreviewls"/> If the player submits a correct answer, they are rewarded with the amount of Picarats the puzzle is worth,<ref name="noegameplay"/> and the plot will progress.<ref name="lsmanualp13b"/> After completing a puzzle, it can be played again at any time from the Puzzle Index, a section in the game's interface that lists the puzzles a player has completed.<ref name="noegameplay">{{cite web | url = https://www.nintendo.co.uk/NOE/en_GB/games/ms/plsc/gameplay.html | title = Professor Layton and the Spectre's Call – Gameplay | publisher = Nintendo of Europe | work = Professor Layton and the Spectre's Call – Official Website | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/639IK3xFH?url=http://www.nintendo.co.uk/NOE/en_GB/games/ms/plsc/gameplay.html | archivedate = November 12, 2011 | deadurl = yes | accessdate = November 12, 2011}}</ref> Occasionally, after completing a puzzle, the player will receive small items that can be used in [[minigame]]s. Fulfilling certain criteria, such as clearing all levels in a minigame, unlock additional puzzles in the Bonuses section.
Players are also capable of connecting to [[Nintendo Wi-Fi Connection]] in order to [[Downloadable content|download]] additional puzzles in the "Bonuses" mode, which can be selected from the game's title screen. These puzzles to be are made available each week following the game's release.<ref name="noegameplay"/> Hints for these puzzles could not be purchased with hint coins, but they were provided freely one week after the puzzle was made available, for 33 weeks.<ref name="lsmanualp25">{{cite book | title = Professor Layton and the Last Specter Instruction Booklet | section = Weekly Nintendo Wi-Fi Connection Puzzles | publisher = Nintendo of America | date = October 17, 2011 | quote = When available, hints will be provided for downloaded puzzles one week after their release. The first time you connect and download puzzles from Nintendo WFC, all currently available puzzles and hints will be downloaded. |page = 25}}</ref> A 34th puzzle was produced but never issued.{{Citation needed|date=May 2014}} When a player connected to Nintendo Wi-Fi Connection, all puzzles and hints would be downloaded.<ref name="lsmanualp25"/> After May 20, 2014, it's no longer possible to download the additional content, as the [[Nintendo Wi-Fi Connection]] service was terminated on that date.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.nintendo.co.uk/Support/Nintendo-DSi-XL-/Basic-setup-and-use/Termination-of-Nintendo-Wi-Fi-Connection/Titles-with-additional-downloadable-content/Titles-with-additional-downloadable-content-864190.html | title = Titles with additional downloadable content | publisher = [[Nintendo]] | accessdate = May 15, 2014}}</ref>
===Minigames=== ''Professor Layton and the Last Specter'' also features several small minigames that are playable in the main game, available by selecting them from the Professor's Suitcase located in the top-right corner of the bottom screen while moving about the town. In order to play these minigames, the plot must have progressed far enough to have [[unlockable (gaming)|unlocked]] each of them, and more difficult levels require the completion of puzzles in the main game.<ref name="eurogamerlsrev">{{cite web | last = Teti | first = John | url = http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2011-10-21-professor-layton-and-the-last-specter-review | title=Professor Layton and the Last Specter | publisher = [[Eurogamer]] | date = October 21, 2011 | accessdate = October 21, 2011}}</ref>
The '''Toy Train''' minigame involves laying a [[railroad track]] across a complex game board. The toy train must pass through every train station and reach a defined end point, and in harder levels, it must be timed to avoid cars and other trains.<ref name="wiredmajinnofue">{{cite web | last = Kohler | first = Chris | url = https://www.wired.com/2009/11/professor-layton/ | title = What's New In Professor Layton's Fourth Outing | publisher = ''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]'' | date = November 30, 2009 | accessdate = April 11, 2016}}</ref> The toy train requires [[fuel]] to move, limiting the amount of track that can be placed by a player unless more fuel is collected before a track ends.<ref name="wiredmajinnofue"/>
The '''Fish''' minigame involves manipulating a fish to collect every coin in its tank. The fish moves in a straight diagonal line, and the player can alter this line by placing bubbles at certain marked points, [[reflection (physics)|reflect]]ing it in a different direction.<ref name="noewhatsnew"/> In the Japanese version of ''Last Specter'', the Fish minigame is instead based on trying to create words by feeding them to fish, who alter them in specific patterns.<ref name="wiredmajinnofue"/>
In the '''Puppet Theater''' minigame, the player is tasked with finishing the script of an ongoing play so that it makes sense.<ref name="wiredmajinnofue"/> If the player chooses a word that does not make sense in the context of the play, the play abruptly ends and the player is asked to try again; if all of the right words are chosen, the play is given an [[epilogue]] and an audience applauds.
After progressing far enough into the story, the player can tap mice across Misthallery to earn "mouse badges" and gain access to another minigame, entitled '''Mouse Alley'''.<ref name="noewhatsnew"/><ref name="grevreview">{{cite web | last = Tan | first = Nick | url = http://www.gamerevolution.com/review/professor-layton-and-the-last-spectre | title=Professor Layton and the Last Specter Review | publisher = [[Game Revolution]] | date = October 10, 2011 | accessdate = October 11, 2011}}</ref> Unlike the other minigames, this is accessed through a character in Misthallery and not through the Trunk. The goal of the minigame is to tap as many mice as possible within the time limit, while avoiding tapping Luke's mouse, Toppy, by mistake. This is the only real-time element in the game.
== Plot ==
===Setting=== ''Professor Layton and the Last Specter'' takes place three years before the events of ''Professor Layton and the Curious Village'' in a fictional English village known as Misthallery.<ref name="l5iapr">{{cite web | url = http://level5ia.com/news/professor-layton-and-the-last-specter-is-in-stores-now/ | title=Professor Layton and the Last Specter is in Stores Now! | publisher = Level-5 International America | date = October 17, 2011 | accessdate = November 5, 2011}}</ref> In Misthallery, citizens have long spoken of legends of a [[Ghost|specter]] who rose from the mist to defend the village whenever the Specter's Flute was played. Lately, a monster who is believed by the town's population to be this specter has been attacking the village during the middle of the night, destroying homes and buildings.<ref name="l5iapr"/>
Misthallery is a watery town in which traveling via [[gondola]] to move about the town's [[canal]]s is commonplace.<ref name="limbsofthetown">{{cite video game | title = Professor Layton and the Last Specter | developer = [[Level-5 (company)|Level-5]] | publisher = Nintendo | date = October 17, 2011 | platform = [[Nintendo DS]] | version = 1.0 | scene = Layton's Journal | level = The Limbs of the Town | quote = The canals that wind through Misthallery are not just for show. They are also a useful means of transportation for the inhabitants, which is evident from the number of piers and small boats moored about town.}}</ref> By these canals, the town is divided into five distinct regions: the Crossroads, the Market, the East District, Ely Street, and Highyard Hill. The Crossroads contain the library as well as the home of the mayor, Clark Triton. The town market is a shady place controlled by a mysterious entity known as the Black Raven,<ref name="theblackravens">{{cite video game | title = Professor Layton and the Last Specter | developer = Level-5 | publisher = Nintendo | date = October 17, 2011 | platform = Nintendo DS | version = 1.0 | scene = Layton's Journal | level = The Black Ravens | quote = When we arrived at the auction all, the Black Raven himself was waiting for us. At first glance, it is hard to tell who or what this Black Raven is, but it is clear to me that he is simply made up of a group of children, albeit remarkably clever children. By creating this fantastical character, they were able to set their elaborate tests and select clients for the Black Market.}}</ref> the East District contains an abandoned warehouse,<ref name="totheoldfactory">{{cite video game | title = Professor Layton and the Last Specter | developer = Level-5 | publisher = Nintendo | date = October 17, 2011 | platform = Nintendo DS | version = 1.0 | scene = Layton's Journal | level = To the Old Factory | quote = Thanks to the Black Ravens' help in examining the results of our trap, we now know that the specter was heading to the abandoned factory. As I recall, the factory is east of the Grand Bridge.}}</ref> and Ely Street as well as Highyard Hill are primarily [[residential area]]s. On the outskirts of Highyard Hill lies the manor owned by the former mayor's children, who live away from the rest of the village. The townspeople believe that the manor is home to a witch.<ref name="thegirlwhowascalledawitch">{{cite video game | title = Professor Layton and the Last Specter | developer = Level-5 | publisher = Nintendo | date = October 17, 2011 | platform = Nintendo DS | version = 1.0 | scene= Layton's Journal | level = The Girl Who Was Called a Witch | quote = Arianna, the infamous "calamity witch," turned out to be quite an ordinary little girl, although she seemed to harbor a great deal of bitterness and hostility. She is convinced that her life is cursed.}}</ref> The town is also rumored to contain the Golden Garden, hidden ruins of an ancient city.<ref name="noegallery">[https://www.nintendo.co.uk/NOE/en_GB/games/ms/plsc/gallery.html]{{Dead link|date=April 2016}}</ref>
===Story=== [[File:Last Specter Cutscene.png|thumb|right|A still from one of the animated cutscenes within ''Professor Layton and the Last Specter''.]] As the story begins, a woman named Emmy Altava is hired to be Professor Layton's assistant at the fictional Gressenheller University. Upon her introduction to him, he reveals that he is currently heading towards a town named Misthallery. According to a letter allegedly sent by his close friend, Clark Triton, a specter is attacking the village at night. As the pair reach Clark's house, though, they find that the letter was sent not by Clark, but by his son, Luke, who has learned how to predict the specter's attacks and wished to enlist Layton's help in putting an end to them.<ref name="noegallery"/> Luke sneaks out of his house to join Layton and Emmy's investigation. After they finish exploring Misthallery for the day, they go to spend the night at a local hotel. As they look out from the window in their room, they hear the sound of a flute and see a large, shadowy figure emerge from the [[mist]], which proceeds to forge a path of destruction through the town, including their hotel room, before vanishing without a trace.
The next day, Layton, Luke, and Emmy set off to find the town's [[black market]] in order to discover information about the Specter's Flute, an artifact which is said grant those who play it control over the specter. After winning the trust of the Black Raven, a group of children who run the market,<ref name="theblackravens"/> Layton learns that the flute was auctioned to the now-deceased Evan Barde, once the richest man in Misthallery, soon before the specter started attacking the town. The three then head to Barde Manor to visit his daughter, Arianna, a girl who was once close friends with Luke, but is now suffering from a [[terminal illness]] and is believed by the townspeople to be a witch.<ref name="thegirlwhowascalledawitch"/>
Arianna refuses to talk to anyone, however, so Layton and Luke continue to question the townspeople while Emmy goes to the [[Scotland Yard]] for information regarding Evan Barde's death. With the aid of Inspectors Chelmey and Grosky, she uncovers the records for the case before heading back to Misthallery to reunite with Layton and Luke.<ref name="foundthedocuments">{{cite video game | title = Professor Layton and the Last Specter | developer = Level-5 | publisher = Nintendo | date = October 17, 2011 | platform = Nintendo DS | version = 1.0 | scene = Layton's Journal | level = Found the Documents! | quote = With some extra help from Inspector Chelmey, we managed to find the reports we were looking for. I also got my photographs developed, so I'm all set to go back to Misthallery. I might have accidentally picked up Inspector Grosky too...}}</ref> Inspector Grosky returns with her, hoping that his own influence will help convince the town's [[Chief of Police]], Chief Jakes, to provide further information on the case. Regardless, Chief Jakes remains adamantly opposed to the investigation of Barde's death, and demands that Layton and company leave the town within 24 hours.<ref name="wegettheblame">{{cite video game | title = Professor Layton and the Last Specter | developer = Level-5 | publisher = Nintendo | date = October 17, 2011 | platform = Nintendo DS | version = 1.0 | scene = Layton's Journal | level = We Get the Blame? | quote = We managed to witness the specter again, but as we set off after it, we were caught by Jakes and his men and forcibly taken to the police station. Does Jakes really think that we were behind all this? I very much doubt it. No, I believe there is something that Jakes doesn't want us to uncover...}}</ref> Despite Jakes' threats, they visit Arianna to explain to her what has happened to the town and to her father. Arianna opens up to them, and proceeds to guide them to the nearby lake before playing the Specter's Flute, which causes a prehistoric aquatic creature named Loosha to rise from the lake.
Chief Jakes then appears at the lake, revealing that he had followed the Professor, and takes Arianna and Loosha into [[police custody]], claiming them to be behind the specter attacks. In his absence, the trio manage to find the real "specter" at an abandoned factory within the town.<ref name="totheoldfactory"/> As Arianna and Loosha are being formally accused in front of the townspeople, Layton appears and exposes the true identity of the specter: an [[excavation (archaeology)|excavation]] machine destroying the town in search of the "Golden Garden", ancient ruins believed to be beneath Misthallery.<ref name="noegallery"/> He goes on to describe Chief Jakes' scheme to become mayor of the town and his accomplice: a man disguised as Clark's butler, Doland Noble, named Jean Descole, a scientist looking for the Golden Garden who had held hostage Clark's wife along with his real butler.<ref name="emmytotherescue">{{cite video game | title = Professor Layton and the Last Specter | developer = Level-5 | publisher = Nintendo | date = October 17, 2011 | platform = Nintendo DS | version = 1.0| scene = Art | level = Emmy to the Rescue | quote = Emmy helps the real Doland and Clark's wife, Brenda, escape from the cellar. What a relief to find them alive and well!}}</ref> With Descole's plan revealed, he combines his machines into a giant [[mecha]] in a final attempt to level the town in search of the Golden Garden.
With the combined efforts of Layton, Luke, Emmy, Loosha, and the Black Ravens, the mecha is eventually defeated and Descole is forced to retreat. Despite Loosha having been fatally wounded during the fight, she proceeds to destroy the floodgates of the town's dam, drying the lake and revealing the entrance to the Golden Garden.<ref name="paradisefound">{{cite video game | title = Professor Layton and the Last Specter | developer = Level-5 | publisher = Nintendo | date = October 17, 2011 | platform = Nintendo DS | version = 1.0 | scene = Layton's Journal | level = Paradise Found | quote = Though the struggle was over and the town saved, the badly wounded Loosha fought on to knock down the last floodgates, draining the lake of water and revealing a hidden door. When we solved the puzzle and opened the door, before us lay a paradise of lush greenery, an entire ecosystem... We had found the Golden Garden. Loosha had used the last of her strength to find a cure for Arianna.}}</ref> As the group enter the garden, Loosha dies, and Arianna learns of Loosha's true intentions. Loosha knew that the clean environment of the garden would help Arianna recover from her disease, and fought the specter to ensure the garden would survive long enough to cure her.<ref name="paradisefound"/> She fully recovers from her illness a year later, and the Golden Garden's discovery is then made public, marking the beginning of Layton's fame in the field of archaeology.
As Luke leaves the garden, he realizes he still has much to learn about the world, and asks to become Layton's apprentice. Layton obliges, and the game ends with Luke bidding farewell to the people of Misthallery before beginning his journeys with Layton. In a final scene, Jean Descole is seen on a cart, preparing his next plan.
==''Professor Layton's London Life''== [[File:London Life Title.png|thumb|right|200px|Gameplay from ''London Life''. Players perform errands for various characters from the ''Professor Layton'' series.]] {{nihongo|'''''Professor Layton's London Life'''''|レイトン教授のロンドンライフ|Layton-kyōju no Rondon Raifu}} is a role-playing game developed in cooperation with [[Brownie Brown]], included with ''Professor Layton and the Last Specter''.<ref name="ascomb1i">{{cite web | last = Gantayat | first = Anoop | url = http://andriasang.com/comb1i/layton_london_life/ | title = Professor Layton Gets a 100 Hour RPG | publisher = Andriasang | date = August 25, 2009 | accessdate = April 11, 2016}}</ref> In ''London Life'', the player creates an [[avatar (computing)|avatar]] that can later be customized with clothing and accessories. With this avatar, players live in "Little London", a small city inspired by London.<ref name="l5iapr"/> Within Little London, the player can create and decorate their own room and perform errands for the townspeople, who consist of many characters from all four games in the ''Professor Layton'' series at the time of its creation.<ref name="l5iapr"/> The game also includes characters from the animated movie released later the same year, ''[[Professor Layton and the Eternal Diva]]'', such as singer Janice Quatlane as well as Melina and Oswald Whistler.<ref name="laytonjpll">{{cite web | url = http://www.layton.jp/majin/london.html | script-title = ja:レイトン教授のロンドンライフ 秘密のパスワードを公開！| language = Japanese | publisher = Level-5 Inc. | work = Layton Japan | accessdate = October 11, 2011}}</ref> By aiding the townspeople, players can gain items or furniture that can be used to access new areas of the city, as well as wealth and happiness.<ref name="l5iapr"/><ref name="ascomb1i"/> Players can also use Nintendo Wi-Fi Connection to [[upload]] their avatar to the Internet, to be downloaded by other players with whom they have traded [[friend code]]s.<ref name="lsmanualp37">{{cite book | title = Professor Layton and the Last Specter Instruction Booklet | section = Fun With Wireless Communications | publisher = Nintendo of America | date = October 17, 2011 | quote = After you've progressed far enough in the game, you and a friend can create visiting versions of your own characters in each other's towns via Nintendo Wi-Fi Connection. | page = 37}}</ref> ''London Life'' is advertised to contain over 100 hours worth of gameplay.<ref name="ascomb1i"/> Players can also trade in-game items with others through the Nintendo DS's [[tag mode]] feature, in which the Nintendo DS system communicates wirelessly with other Nintendo DS systems running the same game while in [[sleep mode]].<ref name="wiredmajinnofue"/>
''Professor Layton's London Life'' would later be the basis of another Level-5 title, ''[[Fantasy Life]]''.<ref name="ascomb1i"/><ref name="ascomyl0">{{cite web | last = Gantayat | first = Anoop | url = http://andriasang.com/comyl0/ | title = Level-5 Vision 2011 Live Blog | publisher = Andriasang | date = October 15, 2011 | accessdate = November 5, 2011}}</ref> ''London Life'' can only be played after completing the Japanese version of the main game ''Last Specter'',<ref name="ascomb1i"/> but is accessible from the beginning of the game in North American<ref name="noaexclusive">{{cite web | url = http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20110829005768/en/Legend-Zelda-Skyward-Sword-Bundle-Highlights-Golden | title = The Legend of Zelda: Skyward Sword Bundle Highlights a Golden Autumn for Nintendo Games | publisher = [[Business Wire]] | date = August 29, 2011 | accessdate = April 11, 2016}}</ref> and Australian<ref name="nwrausll">{{cite web | last = Bray | first = Nicholas | url = http://www.nintendoworldreport.com/news/28079/australian-layton-release-to-include-london-life | title = Australian Layton Release to Include London Life | publisher = Nintendo World Report | date = October 14, 2011 | accessdate = April 11, 2016}}</ref> versions of the game. The European versions do not include ''London Life'', because the amount of time it would take to translate the game would otherwise have prevented the game from being released before the end of 2011.<ref name="onmlondonlifeuk">{{cite web | last = East | first = Thomas | url = http://www.officialnintendomagazine.co.uk/29935/professor-laytons-london-life-is-coming-to-europe/ | title = Professor Layton's London Life isn't coming to Europe | publisher = ''[[Official Nintendo Magazine]]'' | date = August 30, 2011 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20141009155746/http://www.officialnintendomagazine.co.uk/29935/professor-laytons-london-life-is-coming-to-europe/ | archivedate = October 9, 2014 | deadurl = yes | accessdate = April 11, 2016}}</ref><ref name="inferioreu">{{cite web | last = Riley | first = Adam | url = http://www.cubed3.com/news/16056/1/nintendo-confirms-inferior-eu-layton.html | title = Nintendo Confirms Inferior EU Layton | publisher = Cubed3 | date = September 15, 2011 | accessdate = April 11, 2016}}</ref><ref name="getalondonlife">{{Cite web | last = Weisen | first = Andrew | url = http://www.ign.com/blogs/andreweisen/2011/11/14/get-a-london-life/ | title = Get a London Life | publisher = IGN | date = November 14, 2011 | accessdate = November 14, 2011}}</ref>
==Development and release==
===Development=== Every puzzle in ''Last Specter'' was created by [[Akira Tago]], a Japanese professor and author of the Atama no Taisō series of puzzle books, which has sold more than 12 million copies within Japan.<ref name="noeparents">[https://www.nintendo.co.uk/NOE/en_GB/games/ms/plsc/parentsfaq.html]{{Dead link|date=April 2016}}</ref> The game was produced by Level-5 CEO [[Akihiro Hino]], and designed around the concept of {{nihongo|"''Nazotoki × Deai no Monogatari''"|「ナゾトキ×出会いの物語」||Lit. "Puzzle-solving and the Story of the Encounter"}}, detailing how Professor Layton met his apprentice, Luke.<ref name="laytonjp">{{cite web | url = http://www.layton.jp/majin/index.html | script-title = ja:レイトン教授シリーズ | language = Japanese | publisher = Level-5 | accessdate = December 21, 2011}}</ref>
The ''Professor Layton'' series was envisioned as a trilogy, to be completed with the release of the third game, ''[[Professor Layton and the Unwound Future]]''.<ref name="1uplasttimetravel">{{cite web | last = Sato | first = Yoshi | url = http://www.1up.com/news/final-professor-layton-game-announced | title = Third (Final!) 'Professor Layton' Game Announced | publisher = 1UP.com | date = November 28, 2007 | accessdate = November 7, 2011 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20131005012738/http://www.1up.com/news/final-professor-layton-game-announced | archivedate = October 5, 2013 | df = mdy-all }}</ref> In spite of this, Hino said that, during the development of ''Unwound Future'', Level-5 had received a lot of questions from gamers asking if it was "really the end [of the series]", which was all of the inspiration he needed to create a "second season" of the ''Professor Layton'' series.<ref name="1updevilsflute">{{cite web | last = Gifford | first = Kevin | url = http://www.1up.com/news/professor-layton-trilogy | title = Professor Layton and the New DS Trilogy | publisher = 1UP.com | date = March 11, 2009 | accessdate = November 7, 2011}}</ref> In March 2009, Akihiro Hino officially unveiled ''Professor Layton and the Last Specter'' in ''[[Famitsu]]'', stating that, with the second season, each game would take longer to develop than before, to dispel beliefs that ''Professor Layton'' had not significantly changed with each passing game.<ref name="1updevilsflute"/> The second season of the series was also scheduled to have animated movies that take place between the games, starting with ''Professor Layton and the Eternal Diva'', which was announced alongside ''Last Specter''.<ref name="1updevilsflute"/><ref name="ascome64">{{cite web | last = Gantayat | first = Anoop | url = http://andriasang.com/come64/layton_plans/ | title = Level-5 Details Professor Layton Plans | publisher = Andriasang | date = November 25, 2009 | accessdate = April 11, 2016}}</ref>
===Soundtrack=== {{listen | filename = Last Specter Theme.ogg | title = "The Last Specter's Theme" | description = Sample of "The Last Specter's Theme", displaying the game's musical style. | format = [[Ogg]] }} In Japan, the music featured within the game was released as a soundtrack: the {{nihongo|''Layton-kyōju to Majin no Fue Original Soundtrack''|レイトン教授と魔神の笛 オリジナル・サウンドトラック|Professor Layton and the Specter's Flute Original Soundtrack}}.<ref name="semlstracklist">{{cite web|url=http://www.squareenixmusic.com/albums/p/professorlayton4.shtml|title=Professor Layton and the Devil's Flute Original Soundtrack|accessdate=November 1, 2011|publisher=Square Enix Music|year=2009}}</ref> The ending theme, {{nihongo|"Paxmáveiti"|Paxmáveiti ラフマベティ -君が僕にくれたもの-|Paxmáveiti Lafumabety -Kimiga Bokuni Kuretamono-}}, sung by [[Yūko Andō (singer)|Yūko Andō]],<ref name="ascome61"/> was omitted from the soundtrack, and was also replaced with an [[instrumental]] version of the song in international releases of the game.<ref name="semlstracklist"/><ref name="vgmdbpax">{{cite web | url = http://vgmdb.net/album/16129 | title = Paxmáveiti -Kimi ga Boku ni Kuretamono- (Limited Edition) | publisher = VGMdb | accessdate=November 1, 2011}}</ref><ref name="lsmanualp26">{{cite book | title = Professor Layton and the Last Specter Instruction Booklet | section = Professor Layton and the Last Specter Staff Credits | publisher = Nintendo of America | date = October 17, 2011 | quote = Ending Theme Music – Paxmaveiti (Lafumabety) -Kimiga Bokuni Kuretamono-; Composer: Yuko Ando, Bass: Hajime Niwa, Drums: Mikio Yamabe, Guitar: Teiji Taguchi, Piano: Shoko Tsukioka, Violin/Viola: Tatsunobu Goto | page = 26}}</ref> The game also reuses music from ''Diabolical Box'' and ''Unwound Future''.
The game's musical score has been met very positively. Square Enix Music Online rated the soundtrack an eight out of ten,<ref name="semlsreview">{{cite web | author = Mac_Tear | url = http://www.squareenixmusic.com/reviews/mactear/professorlayton4.shtml | title = Professor Layton and the Devil's Flute Original Soundtrack | publisher = Square Enix Music Online | accessdate = November 1, 2011}}</ref> stating that it "goes a little step further compared to its ancestors", and praised the quality of the orchestral renditions, calling them "superior to Professor Layton and the [Unwound Future], which already had fantastic arrangements."<ref name="semlsreview"/> RPGfan likewise praised the orchestral songs, and also spoke highly of the rest of the soundtrack, particularly "The Last Specter's Theme", stating that it was "sure to win over most any video game music fan."<ref name="rpgfanostrev">{{cite web | last = Gann | first = Patrick | url = http://www.rpgfan.com/soundtracks/proflayton4/index.html | title = Professor Layton and the Devil's Flute OST | publisher = RPGFan | accessdate = November 1, 2011}}</ref>
{{Track listing | collapsed = no | headline = Professor Layton and the Last Specter Original Soundtrack | extra_column = English Localization | total_length = 64:28 | title1 = 魔神の笛の旋律 | extra1 = The Specter's Melody | length1 = 0:22 | title2 = 魔神の笛のテーマ | extra2 = The Last Specter's Theme | length2 = 3:50 | title3 = 魔神出現 | extra3 = The Specter Appears | length3 = 1:01 | title4 = 水の町~ミストハレリ昼 | extra4 = Misthallery's Many Canals | length4 = 3:26 | title5 = 謎5 | extra5 = More Puzzles | length5 = 2:28 | title6 = 不思議な話 | extra6 = A Strange Story | length6 = 2:22 | title7 = 風の町~ハイヤードヒル | extra7 = The Wind on Highyard Hill | length7 = 2:33 | title8 = 影のある邸宅 | extra8 = The Darkened Manor | length8 = 2:34 | title9 = 穏やかな午後 | extra9 = A Quiet Afternoon | length9 = 1:42 | title10 = ランブル! | extra10 = Rumble! | length10 = 1:52 | title11 = 謎6~推理 | extra11 = Puzzle Deductions | length11 = 2:33 | title12 = 闇市場 | extra12 = The Black Market | length12 = 2:00 | title13 = 静かな時間 | extra13 = A Quiet Moment | length13 = 1:19 | title14 = 霧の町~ミストハレリ夜 | extra14 = Foggy Misthallery | length14 = 3:29 | title15 = 教授のカバン~ミラクルフィッシュ | extra15 = The Fish | length15 = 2:20 | title16 = 教授のカバン~人形劇 | extra16 = The Puppets | length16 = 2:13 | title17 = 教授のカバン~ミニチュアトレイン | extra17 = The Toy Train | length17 = 1:51 | title18 = ゴーストファクトリー | extra18 = The Abandoned Factory | length18 = 2:09 | title19 = デスコールのテーマ | extra19 = Descole's Theme | length19 = 2:44 | title20 = ラストバトルのテーマ | extra20 = The Final Battle | length20 = 4:03 | title21 = 伝説の楽園 | extra21 = The Golden Garden | length21 = 4:09 | title22 = 楽園の守り神~ラグーシのテーマ | extra22 = Loosha's Theme | length22 = 2:55 | title23 = 謎5 <生演奏ヴァージョン> | extra23 = More Puzzles (Live Version) | length23 = 4:18 | title24 = ラストバトルのテーマ <生演奏ヴァージョン> | extra24 = The Final Battle (Live Version) | length24 = 3:32 | title25 = デスコールのテーマ <生演奏ヴァージョン> | extra25 = Descole's Theme (Live Version) | length25 = 2:43 }}
===Release=== Though the game was released within Japan during November 2009,<ref name="ascome61">{{cite web | last = Gantayat | first = Anoop | url = http://andriasang.com/come61/layton_red_carpet/ | title = Level-5 Gives New Layton Red Carpet Premiere | publisher = Andriasang | date = November 25, 2009 | accessdate = April 11, 2016}}</ref> the game did not appear at [[E3 2010]] alongside ''Unwound Future'' and the [[Nintendo 3DS]] sequel to ''Last Specter'', ''[[Professor Layton and the Miracle Mask]]'', which were both announced at the event.<ref name="pgunwoundfuture">{{cite web | last = Jordan | first = Jon | url = http://www.pocketgamer.co.uk/r/DS/Professor+Layton+and+the+Unwound+Future/news.asp?c=21485 | title = E3 2010: Hands on with Professor Layton and the Unwound Future | publisher = [[Pocket Gamer]] | date = June 16, 2010 | accessdate = November 7, 2011}}</ref><ref name="pgmaskofmiracle">{{cite web | last = Maxwell | first = Ben | url = http://www.pocketgamer.co.uk/r/3DS/Professor+Layton+and+the+Mask+of+Miracle/news.asp?c=21501 | title = E3 2010: Professor Layton and the Mask of Miracle heading to 3DS | publisher = Pocket Gamer | date = June 16, 2010 | accessdate=November 7, 2011}}</ref> The game would, for the next year, only be mentioned by Nintendo in passing during an interview involving the [[Nintendo DSi XL]], where it was referred to as ''Professor Layton and the Specter's Flute''.<ref name="iwndsixl">{{cite web | url = http://nintendods.com/iwata-asks-chapter.jsp?interviewId=4&volumeId=1&chapterId=5 | title = Iwata Asks: Nintendo DSi XL, Chapter 5 | publisher = Nintendo | work = Nintendo DS Official Website | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/638Ae6vqg?url=http://nintendods.com/iwata-asks-chapter.jsp?interviewId=4&volumeId=1&chapterId=5 | archivedate = November 12, 2011 | deadurl = yes | accessdate = November 11, 2011 | df = mdy-all }}</ref> At the end of May 2011, Level-5 filed a trademark in the United States for ''Professor Layton and the Last Specter'',<ref name="lastspectername">{{cite web | last = Ronaghan | first = Neal | url = http://www.nintendoworldreport.com/news/26408/fourth-professor-layton-game-trademarked-in-north-america | title = Fourth Professor Layton Game Trademarked in North America | publisher = Nintendo World Report | date = May 26, 2011 | accessdate = April 11, 2016}}</ref> and the game was officially unveiled internationally following [[E3 2011]].<ref name="pglastspecter">{{cite web | last = Schilling | first = Chris |url=http://www.pocketgamer.co.uk/r/DS/Professor+Layton+and+the+Last+Specter/news.asp?c=30511 | title = E3 2011: Professor Layton and the Last Specter confirmed with spooky new shots and trailer | publisher = Pocket Gamer | date = June 8, 2011 | accessdate = November 7, 2011}}</ref> The game was released in North American and PAL regions during late 2011.<ref name="eu name">{{cite web | last = East | first = Thomas | url = http://www.officialnintendomagazine.co.uk/28396/professor-layton-4-uk-name-revealed | title = Professor Layton 4 UK name revealed | publisher = ''Official Nintendo Magazine | date = June 30, 2011 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20141009155829/http://www.officialnintendomagazine.co.uk/28396/professor-layton-4-uk-name-revealed/ | archivedate = October 9, 2014 | deadurl = yes | accessdate = April 11, 2016}}</ref><ref name="lastspectername"/>
After the game's release in Japan during late 2009, ''Professor Layton and the Last Specter'' quickly rose to the top of Japanese sales charts, moving over 300,000 units during its first week,<ref name="lssalesjp">{{cite web | last = Gantayat | first = Anoop | url = http://www.ign.com/articles/2009/12/04/layton-conquers-japan-again | title = Layton Conquers Japan Again | publisher = IGN | date = December 4, 2009 | accessdate = April 12, 2016}}</ref> eventually totaling 659,504 sales in Japan as of December 20, 2010.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://garaph.info/softwaregroup.php?grid=154 | title = Professor Layton | work = Famitsu sales data | publisher = Garaph | accessdate = May 20, 2012}}</ref> When it saw international release during late 2011, it became the best-selling Nintendo DS game in North America on the week of its release – although across all platforms, it was outsold by ''[[Batman: Arkham City]]'' and ''[[Just Dance 3]]'', among other titles.<ref name="gamasturasales">{{cite web | last = Cowan | first = Danny | url = http://gamasutra.com/view/news/38020/Saling_The_World_Batman_Arkham_City_Just_Dance_3_Lead_Domestic_Charts.php | title = Saling the World: Batman: Arkham City, Just Dance 3 Lead Domestic Charts | publisher = [[Gamasutra]] | date = October 21, 2011 | accessdate = October 22, 2011}}</ref> In the United Kingdom, it was the seventh-highest selling game on its week of release, and the third-highest on a single console following both the Xbox 360 and PlayStation 3 versions of ''[[Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 3]].''<ref name="gsuksc">{{cite web | last = Rose | first = Mike | url = http://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/38747/Modern_Warfare_3_Tops_UK_Charts_For_Third_Consecutive_Week.php | title = Modern Warfare 3 Tops UK Charts For Third Consecutive Week | publisher = Gamasutra | date = November 28, 2011 | accessdate = November 29, 2011}}</ref> By the end of 2011, the game totaled 1.19 million sales within North America and Europe,<ref name="ascomzs8">{{cite web | last = Gantayat | first = Anoop | url = http://andriasang.com/comzs8/nintendo_million_sellers/ | title = Your Latest Nintendo Million Sellers List | publisher = Andriasang | date = January 27, 2012 | accessdate = January 27, 2012}}</ref><ref name="nintendopr">{{Cite web | url = https://www.nintendo.co.jp/ir/pdf/2012/120127e.pdf | title = Financial Results Briefing for the Nine-Month Period Ended December 2011 | publisher = [[Nintendo]] | date = January 27, 2012 | format = PDF | accessdate = January 27, 2012}}</ref> where it has sold 1.25 million copies as of March 2012.<ref name="mar12">{{cite web | url = https://www.nintendo.co.jp/ir/pdf/2012/120427e.pdf#page=7 | title = Financial Results Briefing for Fiscal Year Ended March 2012 | publisher = Nintendo | date = April 27, 2012 | format = PDF | page = 6 | accessdate = May 14, 2012}}</ref>

https://web.archive.org/web/20111223200602/http://www.1up.com/reviews/professor-layton-last-specter-nintendo-ds | archivedate = December 23, 2011 | df = mdy-all }}</ref><ref name="lsgameprorev"/><ref name="lsgradarreview">{{cite web | last = Gudmundson | first = Carolyn | url = http://www.gamesradar.com/professor-layton-and-last-specter-review/ | title = Professor Layton and the Last Specter review | publisher = [[GamesRadar]] | date = October 17, 2011 | accessdate = October 17, 2011}}</ref> [[IGN]] shared these sentiments, but found that the game had "an added attention to detail that makes the whole game feel a bit sharper and more magnificent" than its predecessors.<ref name="ignreviewls"/> The game's puzzles received mixed reception. Reviewers often commented that they felt too similar to puzzles from the other games in the series,<ref name="ignreviewls"/><ref name="eurogamerlsrev"/><ref name="lsgradarreview"/> and several felt that they tended to be vague<ref name="1upreview"/><ref name="lsgameprorev"/> or inconsistent in difficulty.<ref name="1upreview"/><ref name="grevreview"/> Despite this, ''[[GamePro]]'' felt that the game's puzzles were "more balanced" than those from previous games.<ref name="lsgameprorev"/> The game's cutscenes and visuals were very well received, with [[GamesRadar]] describing the cutscenes as "near-[[Studio Ghibli|Ghibli]] quality"<ref name="lsgradarreview"/> and IGN saying that "the graphics, which make use of a cartoony yet beautifully detailed, painterly art style, are simply gorgeous."<ref name="ignreviewls"/>
''Professor Layton's London Life'' was also viewed as a worthwhile extension to the game, with [[1UP.com]] stating that the main game was "almost a side diversion" in comparison.<ref name="1upreview"/> Critics often compared the gameplay to the popular ''[[Animal Crossing]]'' franchise.<ref name="lsgameprorev"/><ref name="eurogamerlsrev"/><ref name="grevreview"/> Response to the game was mixed. IGN felt it "surprising the game was included as a mere bonus"<ref name="ignreviewls"/> and GamePro praised the dialogue, calling it "clever and genuinely funny in ways that few other games are."<ref name="lsgameprorev"/> However, [[Game Revolution]] said that the game soon "becomes a chore" to play,<ref name="grevreview"/> and some reviewers were unhappy with the decision to remove the game from European versions of ''Professor Layton and the Last Specter''.<ref name="eurogamerlsrev"/><ref name="lsgradarreview"/>
''[[The Escapist (magazine)|The Escapist]]'' gave ''Last Specter'' a score of four-and-a-half stars out of five, saying, "Another Professor Layton game, another bit of puzzling brilliance. Some of the brain teasers feel a bit recycled - instead of foxes and chickens, you're shuttling dogs and cats across the river, for example - but there's more than enough variety to warrant doggedly tracking down every last one. But if you only solve the ones you need to move the story forward, that's ok, too."<ref name="escapistrev"/> ''[[The Guardian]]'' gave it four stars out of five, saying, "If you've not been a fan of the series, this isn't the game that's going to change your mind. For everybody else though, ''Professor Layton & The Spectre's Call'' is several days of commute-improving, grey cell stimulation in a mostly effective package. And bravo to Nintendo for keeping this franchise on the standard DS rather than – for the time being, at least – adding that third dimension."<ref name="guardianrev">{{cite news | last = Davey | first = Neil | url = https://www.theguardian.com/technology/gamesblog/2011/nov/23/professor-layton-spectres-call-review | title = Professor Layton & The Spectre's Call - review | newspaper = [[The Guardian]] | date = November 23, 2011 | accessdate = April 12, 2016}}</ref> However, ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' gave it two-and-a-half stars out of five, saying, "The Layton charm is undoubtedly still present, but it's not enough to carry the series by itself. Upon solving certain puzzles, Layton exclaims 'I love the thrill of a good solution'. So do we, Hershel, so do we. And in this Layton game, sadly, that thrill is all too rare."<ref name="telegraphrev"/>
{{clear}}

{{main|Music of Madagascar}} [[File:Jaojoby concert.jpg|300px|thumb|right|Salegy artist Jaojoby performing in Paris]] '''Salegy''' {{IPA-mg|ˈsaleɡʲ|}} is a popular music genre from [[Madagascar]]. Originating as a [[List of Sub-Saharan African folk music traditions|Sub-Saharan African folk music]] style in the northwestern coastal areas of Madagascar, modern salegy is the genre of [[Music of Madagascar|Malagasy music]] that has gained the widest recognition and commercial popularity in the international market. Its sound is considered emblematic of the island.<ref name="afropop"/> [[Eusèbe Jaojoby]], a [[Sakalava people |Sakalava]] singer from [[Antsiranana]], was a key originator of the style and is widely considered the "King of Salegy".<ref name=rfimusique>{{cite web | last = Radio France International (RFI) | title = Jaojoby | publisher = rfimusique.com | date = September 2008 | url = http://www.rfimusique.com/siteEn/biographie/biographie_6279.asp |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/62cbnGHP4 |archivedate = October 20, 2011 | accessdate = December 16, 2006}}</ref>
The contemporary, electrified form of popular salegy originated from traditional acoustic roots in northwestern Madagascar around [[Mahajanga]] and [[Antsiranana]] in the 1950s.<ref name="Randrianary">{{Cite book | last = Randrianary | first = Victor | title = Madagascar: les chants d'une île | publisher = Actes Sud | year = 2001 | isbn = 978-2-7427-3556-3 | language=French}}</ref> It has been popularized by originators like [[Eusèbe Jaojoby|Jaojoby]] and relative newcomers such as [[Ninie Doniah]], [[Vaiavy Chila]] and [[Dr. J.B. and the Jaguars]]. The style is [[funk]]y and energetic, dominated by ringing [[electric guitar]]s, real or synthesized [[accordion]], and [[Call and response (music)|call-and-response]] [[Polyphony|polyphonic vocals]], propelled by heavy [[electric bass]] and a driving [[percussion]] section typically including a [[drum kit]], [[djembe]] and [[Shaker (percussion)|shakers]].<ref name="afropop">{{cite web | last = Eyre | first = Banning | title = Salegy | publisher = Afropop.com | url = http://www.afropop.org/explore/style_info/ID/28/salegy/ |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/62ccCkUAj | archivedate = October 20, 2011| accessdate = October 10, 2010}}</ref> The syncopated, [[polyrhythm]]ic beat of salegy is rapid (typically around 290BPM) and features a distinctive percussion pattern performed on a Western drum kit in [[6/8 time|{{music|time|6|8}}]] or {{music|time|12|4}} time with accents on the 3rd or 7th beat. The melody and harmonies are often in the A minor key and feature beautiful high-life electric guitar and synthesized accordion lines. The sound of salegy can be heard at night clubs, cabarets, parties and dance floors across the island.
Salegy represents an electrified version of the ''antsa'' musical style that was traditionally performed at [[Betsimisaraka people|Betsimisaraka]] and [[Tsimihety people|Tsimihety]] rituals.<ref name="Anderson, I. 2000 pp. 523">{{Citation | last = Anderson | first = Ian | title = The Rough Guide to World Music, Vol. 1: Africa, Europe and the Middle East | publisher = Rough Guides | year = 2000 | chapter =Ocean Music from Southeast Africa | pages =523–532 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=gyiTOcnb2yYC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false | accessdate = November 17, 2010 | isbn = 978-1-84353-551-5}}</ref> In addition to their commonalities in tempo, vocal style, and tendency toward [[minor key]]s (which some attribute to an [[Arab]] influence, and which stands in contrast to the [[major key]] dominance of Highland music), the salegy shares the antsa's structure in that it always features a middle section called the ''folaka'' ("broken") which is primarily instrumental—voice serves only to urge on more energetic dancing—and during which the vocalists (and the audience) will launch into intricate polyrhythmic [[Clapping|hand-clapping]] to the beat of the music.<ref name="Randrianary"/>
==Artists and bands== *[[Anziza Salema]] *Arsène Félix *[[Dr. J.B. and the Jaguars]] *Fenoamby *[[Eusèbe Jaojoby]] *Fredy de Majunga *Gérard Tsapalôko *IO Anay *[[Jaojoby Junior]] *Joacin-tapaka *Lazard *[[Mily Clément]] *Mister Rotsirotsy *[[Ninie Doniah]] *[[Www.olgadelmadagascar.org|Olga del Madagascar]] *Paskaal Japhet *[[Tianjama]] *[[Vaiavy Chila]] *[[Wawa (Malagasy musician)|Wawa]]

{{Multiple issues| {{unreferenced|date=December 2009}} {{tone|date=October 2012}} }}
'''Self-working [[Magic (illusion)|magic]]''' is [[stage magic|magic]] that works simply from following a procedure that is known to the audience. It requires no secret set-up, trickery, [[sleight-of-hand]], or other hidden objects or moves. Some self-working magic allows the audience to have a secret that they do not reveal to the magician until the end. The audience can be told every step, and can even repeat the trick. It can be done alone, since the "magician" may be just as surprised as anybody. All the magician has to do is follow a certain procedure, and everything will be good. [[Optical illusion]]s and some other science demonstrations could fall into this category. The wonder comes from unexpectedness of a natural phenomenon. Basically, self-working magic relies on some expectation or lack of knowledge in the audience about what produces the outcome. Usually, self-working [[card trick]]s revolve around some mathematical principle, such as in the trick "Magical 13", where the spectator is asked to cut the deck 13 times, then split the deck into 13 piles. Upon revealing each pile, it is found that each pile contains only cards of the same value (i.e., one pile has all four fours, the other pile has all four twos, etc.). This is based on the principle that beforehand, the deck is set up with all the suits in order. No matter how many times you cut the deck, the same cards will always be 13 cards away from each other.
==Example== Self-working magic tricks can be baffling in a special way. The [[patter]] can take different forms that make them more entertaining. One variation of patter is to say that you are hiding nothing, and explaining every step of the trick. Some audience members may still think it is a trick. Another variation, possibly with some tricks, is to say, "I will not be doing the magic, here: you will". Another way of doing it is to make a story that explains—gives a reason to—each step, so that no step is hidden, and the audience can even DO the steps, but the audience members are baffled, anyway.
Story: Make a story of cutting the deck 7 times. 7 drunken sailors decide to play a high-stakes poker game with a new deck of cards. (Use a new deck that is ordered correctly for this game, all cards in order in every suit, not backwards order as some decks have, or have the audience put the cards in order to simulate a new deck). Then say, none of them are in a state of mind to shuffle, so they decide to cut the deck 7 times, one time each. The dealer deals but forgets his own 2nd and 4th cards, so he ends up with 3 cards. He asks for 2 more, but the other sailors refuse, arguing, but none of them want to start the round over. They finally agree to let him get 5 new cards. They make their bets, and each sailor bets high, giving up everything he owns. The dealer bets last, and accepts all the bets. Everybody is all in. Finally, they reveal their cards, the dealer revealing last. Every drunken sailor has a full house. But the dealer rarely loses the hand, having usually a straight flush, and sometimes a royal straight flush. Every step of the trick has been told directly to the audience, but they are still amazed.
No magic, here. Say, "No magic, here. You will tell me which cards you picked." Ask the audience to pick 3 cards, not show them to you, and write them down. Make a pile of 10 cards, a pile of 15, another pile of 15, and a pile of 9, in order (no Jokers in the deck). Ask the audience to place the first card face down on the first deck. Then, take any number of cards from the 2nd deck and place them on the 1st. Put the 2nd card on top of the 2nd deck, and put any number of cards from the 3rd deck onto the 2nd deck. Put the 3rd card on top of the 3rd deck. Now, you put the 4th pile on the 3rd, both on the 2nd, and all 3 on the 1st. You have one deck. Take 4 cards from the top and put them on the bottom. You can tell the audience every step you are doing. Now, you can get 0 points to 3 points. I will go thru the deck, and you grab your cards if you see them. If you grab all 3 by the end, you get 3 points, if you grab 1, you get one point, and so on.
Now, put the 1st card face up, the 2nd face down. They will find no cards. Say that is OK, we will keep going. Pick up the face-down deck and keep going. Do it again, and again. They will never see their card. Stop when only 3 cards are left. And say, gee—only 3 cards left. Turn them over, and there are their 3 cards. It works every single time. Sometimes, you can arrange it so that they do not know that they had to memorize the cards after writing them down. They may pick the wrong cards. Show them that they picked the wrong cards by looking at their paper. They will think the trick is over. Then, reveal the correct 3 cards.
==Popular types== 1. Steps of math operations that use some secret knowledge of the audience like their birthday, and then reveal that secret knowledge in an unexpected way at the end. For example, think of any secret 3-digit number, multiply it by one specific number, and then another, and it always comes out a 6-digit number with the original 3 -digit number repeated twice.
2. Another one asks the audience to think of words that start with certain letters, and then words linked to the last letters of those words, asking the audience to reveal only their last choices, but somehow almost always ends with the words "Grey elephant in Denmark" even though the audience thought up their own words throughout the steps.
3. Another one ends up with the audience getting all the same number, but it is the WRONG number! Like an optical illusion, people are susceptible to adding up this particular sequence the wrong way almost every time.
{{DEFAULTSORT:Self-Working Magic}} [[Category:Magic (illusion)]]

[[File:Male whale shark at Georgia Aquarium.jpg|thumb|right|350px|One of the several [[whale shark]]s housed at the [[Georgia Aquarium]]]] Several species of '''[[shark]]s are kept in [[Captivity (animal)|captivity]]''' in public aquaria. In home aquaria, size constraints mean that only the smallest sharks are typically viable as pets.
==Public aquaria== Until recently only a few [[benthic]] species of shark, such as [[Horn shark|hornsharks]], [[Triakis semifasciata|leopard sharks]], [[catshark]]s, and [[zebra shark]]s, had survived in aquarium conditions for up to a year or more. This gave rise to the belief that sharks, as well as being difficult to capture and transport, were difficult to care for. A better knowledge of sharks has led to more species (including the large [[pelagic]] sharks) being able to be kept for far longer. At the same time, transportation techniques have improved and long distance movement of sharks is becoming easier.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mcss.sc/MCNEWS/mcn_v3_1_art3.htm |title=Whale Sharks in Captivity |accessdate=2015-02-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120826131514/http://www.mcss.sc/MCNEWS/mcn_v3_1_art3.htm |archivedate=August 26, 2012 }}</ref> Several attempts to keep a [[Great White Shark]] in captivity have been attempted, but most specimens died or had to be released after a short time. One example, placed in the [[Okinawa Churaumi Aquarium]] in Japan, only survived for three days.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iflscience.com/plants-and-animals/great-white-shark-dies-after-just-three-days-captivity/ |title=Great White Shark Dies After Just THREE Days In Captivity |last=Hale |first=Tom |date=November 1, 2016 |website=IFL Science! |accessdate=2017-04-12}}</ref> The longest a Great White was held in captivity was at the [[Monterey Bay Aquarium]], in September 2004. A young female was kept in an outdoor tank for 198 days before releasing her back into the wild. In the following years, the Monterey Bay Aquarium hosted five more juvenile white sharks for temporary stays before ending their program in 2011.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.vox.com/2016/7/8/12129028/great-white-shark-aquarium|title=Why there aren't any great white sharks in captivity|last=Fong|first=Joss|date=2016-07-08|website=Vox|access-date=2017-06-20}}</ref>
===Behavior=== When introduced to their new habitat some mature sharks has refused food despite the abundance and variety of feeding methods used<ref>Essapian, F. (1962). Notes on the Behavior of Sharks in Captivity. Copeia, 1962(2), 457-459. doi:10.2307/1440936</ref>. Over a period of years this results in sharks dying of starvation amidst plenty<ref>Essapian, F. (1962). Notes on the Behavior of Sharks in Captivity. Copeia, 1962(2), 457-459. doi:10.2307/1440936</ref>. Sharks are usually seen to live a solitary existence, rarely moving about in group events, although, a tank could house up to four or five species during the same time period<ref>Essapian, F. (1962). Notes on the Behavior of Sharks in Captivity. Copeia, 1962(2), 457-459. doi:10.2307/1440936</ref>. It has been commonly seen that Lemon and Nurse sharks occupy the bottom of the tank floor. Occasionally, they will take a swim no more than two or three feet off the bottom<ref>Essapian, F. (1962). Notes on the Behavior of Sharks in Captivity. Copeia, 1962(2), 457-459. doi:10.2307/1440936</ref>. Bull sharks, Sandbar sharks, and Sand tiger sharks continuously swim at mid-depth. Larger tiger sharks inhabit the upper region of the tank where their dorsal fin is breaking the surface frequently<ref>Essapian, F. (1962). Notes on the Behavior of Sharks in Captivity. Copeia, 1962(2), 457-459. doi:10.2307/1440936</ref>. Swimming patterns seen from sharks in captivity are that of Blacktip, Bull, and Lemon sharks being active 24 hours and those of Sandbars, Nurse and Sand tigers being active at certain times of the day/night<ref>Hussain, S. M. (1991). The Behavior of Sharks in Captivity. Indian Journal of Fishtrits. Retrieved April 30, 2018.</ref>. However, within some aquaria’s this could be attributed to the different feeding times of these species<ref>Hussain, S. M. (1991). The Behavior of Sharks in Captivity. Indian Journal of Fishtrits. Retrieved April 30, 2018.</ref>. Sharks in captivity, referring to that of Sandbar, Sand tiger, and Nurse sharks are predicted to be less aggressive being that no aggressive biting is seen after feeding<ref>Flunory, M., Ortiz, M., & Restrepo, A. (n.d.). A Behavioral Study of Sharks in Captivity. Retrieved April 30, 2018.</ref>. The foremost behavior observed from those in captivity was curiosity, reasoning's being due to less competition for food and lack of stimulation<ref>Flunory, M., Ortiz, M., & Restrepo, A. (n.d.). A Behavioral Study of Sharks in Captivity. Retrieved April 30, 2018.</ref>.
==Home aquaria== {{One source|date=January 2009}} Most species of shark are not suitable for domestic aquaria and not every species of shark sold by pet stores make good inhabitants for personal aquaria. Some species of sharks can also be kept well in home saltwater aquaria.<ref name="sharksathomeafm">{{Cite news | last = Michael | first = Scott W. | title = Sharks at Home | newspaper = Aquarium Fish Magazine | pages = 20–29 |date=March 2004 | postscript = <!--None-->}}</ref> Uninformed or unscrupulous dealers sometimes sell juvenile sharks like the [[nurse shark]], which upon reaching adulthood will have far outgrown typical home aquaria.<ref name="sharksathomeafm"/> Public aquaria are generally not interested in accepting donated specimens that have overgrown their housing and some shark owners have been tempted to [[Introduced species|release]] them into the wild.<ref name="sharksathomeafm"/>
===Housings=== However, some species of shark can make prized additions to home aquaria.<ref name="sharksathomeafm"/> Species appropriate to home aquaria represent considerable spatial and financial investments as they generally approach adult lengths of 3 feet and can live up to 25 years.<ref name="sharksathomeafm"/> Sharks must be housed in aquaria at or exceeding 180 gallons in volume, with more active species requiring more space.<ref name="sharksathomeafm"/> Surface area is an even more significant consideration for aquarists than volume as it is the determining factor for the amount of oxygen that ends up being dissolved in the water, and therefore critical to the sharks' respiration.<ref name="sharksathomeafm"/> Choice of aquarium substrate is also important because a sharp, rough bed can irritate a shark's soft underbelly, or in severe cases lead to fatal infections.<ref name="sharksathomeafm"/> Shark aquaria are generally advised to be decorated "conservatively" in order to leave space for the animal to move more freely during daily activities. A cave, however, is often an appropriate addition for some shy species.<ref name="sharksathomeafm"/>
===Diet and nutrition=== Sharks are very frequently overfed by amateur aquarists, which can lead to obesity or unnaturally fast growth rates.<ref name="sharksathomeafm"/> Captive sharks are healthiest when fed at levels similar to their food intake in the wild.<ref name="sharksathomeafm"/> Usually this amounts to 1-3% of their body weight weekly.<ref name="sharksathomeafm"/> However, aquarium conditions and species disposition are considered by conscientious aquarists when feeding captive sharks.<ref name="sharksathomeafm"/> Relatively sedentary species, such as wobbegongs can live on feedings occurring once or twice weekly.<ref name="sharksathomeafm"/> More active species may require to be fed three or four times per week to maintain satisfactory health.<ref name="sharksathomeafm"/> Sharks living in cooler water temperatures have slower metabolisms than sharks in warmer water housings and therefore require less food.<ref name="sharksathomeafm"/>
The most common staple food provided to captive sharks in home aquaria is frozen fish.<ref name="sharksathomeafm"/> The freezing process used to store foods for sharks often results in the food items losing nutrient value.<ref name="sharksathomeafm"/> Lost nutrients are replaced by vitamin supplements, which are marketed commercially, sometimes by companies generally associated with more typical pet foods (such as [[Purina Mills]]).<ref name="sharksathomeafm"/> Uncorrected nutrient deficiencies inherent in the frozen food diet can cause considerable detriment to the health of captive specimens.<ref name="sharksathomeafm"/> Conditions such as popeye, ascites, and anemia are known to occur in captive sharks that are deficient in some essential vitamin.<ref name="sharksathomeafm"/> Vitamin B deficiency results in a treatable condition where the shark's back arches and it swims in a circular motion.<ref name="sharksathomeafm"/>
Feeding sharks frozen non-marine fish can result in deficiencies of omega-3 fatty acids, which can result in "fat infiltration of the liver," which can impede the organ's function seriously enough for major health issues.<ref name="sharksathomeafm"/>
===In community tanks=== Sometimes sharks are unwittingly put in harm's way when aquarists include potentially dangerous tankmates in the same aquarium.<ref name="sharksathomeafm"/> Hobbyists generally don't think of other fish being a threat to sharks, but triggerfish, angel fish, puffers, and wrasses can all injure them.<ref name="sharksathomeafm"/> A large grouper is capable of consuming smaller sharks.<ref name="sharksathomeafm"/> Sometimes docile bottom feeding sharks are put at risk because of the fish that feed on the ocean bottom, sedentary sharks are simply an extension of the substrate."<ref name="sharksathomeafm"/> Another problem aquarists keeping sharks with other types of fish have encountered is that the smaller, more passive aquarium-friendly shark species often have difficulty competing with their tankmates for the food provided by the aquarist.<ref name="sharksathomeafm"/> Sharks are predatory themselves and may maul or consume tankmates smaller or weaker than themselves.<ref name="sharksathomeafm"/>
